No matter what pretext they use to justify this action, it's obvious that it's all about money to them. By forcing a high percentage of their previously satisfied Deluxe customers to pay an additional $30 to upgrade to the Premier product, they're exploiting a weakness of human nature-- fear of and resistance to change-- and demonstrating the worst of human nature themselves: Greed. The sad part is that they will almost surely increase revenue this year. Bad behavior gets rewarded yet again. H&R Block Deluxe claims to be able to import Turbo Tax files from previous years, and appears to have a good reputation, including continuing support for Schedule D in 2014 tax year version. At over 60% less expense than TurboTax Premier, it is worth exploring, and I am purchasing it instead of TurboTax. If I run into problems, I will update this review to that effect. I would encourage others to explore alternatives to Intuit's software, as negative feedback in this case may be the only way to effect positive changes.

title: Virtually Worthless
content: I erred in buying this, thinking it was just like the last many years. This is a completely different and basically worthless product for ANYONE who needed the deluxe version to work as it has in the past. This item is extremely basic at best. I just ordered the H&R Block Deluxe version. It is way cheaper than Turbo Tax ($30 new on Ebay, delivered). It covers Schedules C and D, while the Turbo Deluxe does neither. Plus, it can grab the Turbo Tax files. After many, many years with Turbo Tax I left them because they cut 50% of the functionality out of their Deluxe version without publicizing it. No one should buy from Intuit after this screw up.

title: Intuit, I think you will be getting a pretty strong message this year.
content: I am writing a review because I have used TurboTax for years and years. I loved the program, the ease of use and even with some steady increases in price, I was OK with the cost. After reading the comments, however, I will no longer be using TurboTax. Anyone reading this who urged others not to buy it - here is your first convert. I remember way back when when QuickBooks was super cheap and Intuit was a miracle because of the cost factor. Capitalism is great, but eventually due to the requirement of shareholder returns, greed trumps customer concerns. At that point, consumers must vote with their pocketbooks. I am now voting with mine. My next stop after writing this review is to go to other return provider's websites. Thank you, Intuit, for making me feel powerful in my ability to send a consumer message. Also, as an aside, the fees charged for optional services, such as alternative ways to make payments or receive return funds are ABSURD.

title: Things like this make my blood boil.
content: They know. They KNOW that people buying Deluxe for years will buy it again without reading the proverbial fine print. Then the customer gets to the key point in the program, and it says "GOTCHA!!! We GOTCHA!!! Pony up another thirty bucks or you're out of business!" "What's that? You didn't notice that the product has "changed"? Well, shame on you for being so careless, tsk tsk..." Am I clueless and hopelessly out of touch by having an expectation that I should be treated honestly and fairly? Every day you have to watch for companies trying to get over on you. Go to the supermarket: A pint of Haagen Dazs is now 14 ounces but of course the container size is the same as before. (Wouldn't want the customer to notice.) File an insurance claim, it's unfairly rejected. (Maybe the insured won't notice or care or bother to fight, so it's more profitable this way). Buy Turbo Deluxe as usual - Oops, GOTCHA! Hey Mr. Meighan - Who do you think you're kidding? When you insult my intelligence, you insult me. You insult all of us. Newsflash: Businesses are successful when they treat their customers with honesty and respect. Things go south in a hurry when you go for the cheap buck by deceiving - no, cheating your customers out of their money. Did I mention I'm a tax professional? Wait till I put the word out on this! .

title: Meighan is wrong, you can't paper file Using Deluxe with Schedule D..
content: Bob Meighan, TurboTax VP, said "As I've mentioned in many other places, you are NOT required to upgrade to Premier. You can still use forms mode to complete Schedule D and print/mail your return to the IRS." That doesn't seem to be true. Based on that I bought TurboTax Deluxe. But when you try to print Schedule D it says form "Not Done" and the print has a large "DO NOT FILE" banner across it. Nor does it display the checks that tell you why the form is not done. So you really can't do a paper file.

title: TT Deluxe not what it used to be.
content: Wish I'd read the reviews before purchasing but I've used the deluxe version for years without issue so why should I expect problems? I have a small business and never had any problems with completing Schedule C in the past. But now it seems Sch C is limited in the deluxe version to businesses with less than $100 in expenses so its useless if you have a real business. Now it looks like I'll have to upgrade to home and business if I want to use TT this year. Or maybe now's the time to abandon TT for something else. Way to support your long-term customer base Intuit! Update: Ended up going with the H&R Deluxe. Cheaper, easy import of old TT file and easy transition. A little clunckier when it comes to printing/saving files but end product is the same. Intuit got my $ this year but no more. I'm done with TT, Quicken, and QuickBooks.

title: MISLEADING PRODUCT CHANGE
content: This product has been substantially revised since 2014 by significantly diminishing its applicability. Users (like me) who are used to simply picking up this product for home use should BEWARE...it is NOT the same as last year and it willnot serve your needs....and you will need to buy other software to file your taxes.

title: After almost 20 years, no more Turbo Tax for me
content: After many years of filing my taxes with Turbo Tax, I will not support their bad business decision to cripple the product and force customers to file by mail. Time to find another software to do the job.

title: Bait and Switch - Followed By Awful Customer Support
content: I understand that companies make mistakes, but when mistakes are made a reputable company will fix them. Not with a feeble apology and a partial refund IF you qualify. Our family was forced to pay an additional $40 to upgrade to the "Home and Business" version of the software so that we could file our taxes this year. We were recently informed we could get a $25 refund AFTER FILING if we met certain criteria, filled out a form, and then waited for the folks at Intuit to provide a refund. REALLY??? THAT IS YOUR SOLUTION???? ANY OTHER ACTION THAN UPDATING THE DELUXE VERSION TO INCLUDE THE MISSING SUPPORT, AND REFUNDING THOSE WHO WERE FORCED TO PAY AN UPGRADE FEE DUE TO YOUR BAIT AND SWITCH IS UNACCEPTABLE!!!!! I am extremely disappointed in the leadership, this is an obvious lack of vision and will result in catastrophic consequences for Turbo Tax as a product. Needless to say after a decade of using turbo tax I will be using other products moving forward.

title: horse thieves weren't as dangerous
content: Do not buy this product as it will cost some of you $40 more this year than last after you have to upgrade it when you have bought it. We file a simple return with a sch C.. The Sch C shows $400 minus office expense. The Intuit website says that you can do a simple Sch C using the basic home deluxe which costs the same as last year. It will not let you fill in a single line, and locks up to a page asking you to buy an upgrade. I called Turbo Tax on it as it does not match their advertising, spent 20 minutes on the phone> They said sorry, we wil l fix that, and upgraded it to Premier. Well, guess what - Premier won't do a one line Sch C either. Now I have to spend another 1/2 hour on the phone trying to resolve this again. I could see them asking a little extra for a complex schedule C but really - they get money for the software, then then get money for the E-file, then they get money for a new Quicken every year, and now they want $40 for one of the simplest forms one can have? We are done with this product.

title: What were you thinking??????
content: Who would have thought that TT would change the functionality of the various products to the point where purchasing the same product year after year would no longer provide the same level? The Deluxe should more appropriately be known now as the "Not So Deluxe." I'm one, who after years of using TT, will be seeking another vendor. Will probably give H&R a shot. And Mr. Meighan, what's the deal encouraging people to contact you so you can discuss how TT can keep you as a customer? It's obvious how you can keep everyone as a customer...........undue this deception. You also didn't make it clear that using the forms (manually) will override the audits and checking portions. And also will not allow you to e-file.

title: Now Deluxe is useless to most people
content: Turbo Tax has decided to rip off their loyal customers. Now Deluxe is useless to most people. I have ONE, count it ONE small investment that has a few hundred dollars a year in capital gains. Now I must pay $30 more in order to file all for no other reason then Turbo Tax wants to rip off its customers. I am sure they believe, "yes peopel will be made, but if they use service like H&R block or tohers cost is still higher". That might be and perhaps you do not have much competition now. But I am like all of the other horrible reviews here. I woudl rather spend $200 or $300 with another company or service then give these crocks one dollar of my money. Terrible business decision. Should have just increased each level by $5.00 or something like that. Oh well bye bye turbo tax, hope you end up in deep financial trouble.

title: Corporate Greed has ruined Turbotax deluxe
content: I have been a Turbotax user for years and agree with the one star posts that the changes made to the Deluxe version were unwarranted and based on greed. Taking Schedule D out from the Deluxe version makes this program worthless to me and forces me to buy the premier version. I too will be exploring HR Block and other tax programs.

title: 19 year customer. Done with TT.
content: Been a loyal turbotax user since early 90's. Done now. Very disappointed with elimination of schedule D in deluxe version.

title: This is going to be terrible for the people who just go to Costco etc
content: Ouch. I was just about to buy my usual copy and I saw the crazy ratings. This is going to be terrible for the people who just go to Costco etc. Now for the first time in many years I need to look at the competition. I assume there is some!!

title: I don't know how I didn't see all the reviews ...
content: I don't know how I didn't see all the reviews here when I ordered the same version I have ordered for oh so many years....... Woe is me. Needless to say, I am requesting a refund and am moving on to another method of doing my taxes. I would rather use an abacus than give my allegiance to a company that would trade on my unsuspecting and naive nature. It is unfortunate that Amazon has no method of giving zero stars.

title: Goodbye TurboTax!
content: I am so glad that I checked these reviews before purchasing TurboTax Deluxe for this year. Like many others, I have been using TurboTax for many years. I've had some issues with the software in the past, but have stuck with it until now. Their latest money-grabbing scheme is the last straw. The TurboTax rep has said that the change was done in service of product consistency. Maybe, maybe not...but ultimately, it is an irrelevant point. What is relevant is that the change was done at the expense of their customers. If TurboTax was so inclined, I'm sure they could have found a way to establish product consistency without crippling their alleged "Deluxe" product and creating a "bait and switch" scenario for many of their customers. For informed customers, this change is clearly infuriating, based on the responses on Amazon. The next wave will come from customers who pick it up in the store assuming they are getting the same functionality as in the past and getting an unpleasant surprise...I would not like to be a customer service rep at Intuit right now! I believe in Karma, and I believe that the Intuit executives who made this greed-based decision are going to experience it. I believe that this latest ploy is going to push many TurboTax users to look for alternatives, which will open the market for other companies to establish a stronger foothold and hopefully remove TurboTax's dominance in this market. Personally, I don't intend to use their products again. They have proven that they can't be trusted...

title: Intuit has made big changes for 2014. If you ...
content: Intuit has made big changes for 2014. If you need schedule D (Capital Gains/Losses) you need to move up to the premier version and pay $30.00 more. PLEASE CHECK WHICH VERSIONS SUPPORT WHAT SCHEDULES BEFORE ORDERING!!!

title: ... the Deluxe 2014 I already bought that is now useless and has been tossed
content: And what do they plan to do about the Deluxe 2014 I already bought that is now useless and has been tossed? The hassle of a return is not worth it and I'm surely not going to buy TurboTax and apply for a rebate. Hello H&R Block, you have a new customer.

title: Successful Marketing Campaign
content: Dear Mr. Meighan (VP TurboTax), I want to congratulate you on the most successful marketing and sales campaign in the history of H&R Block. Well done. Enjoy the bonus check I am sure they will be sending you. Bill

title: Switched - thanks for the warning
content: Thanks Amazon reviewers! After using TurboTax Deluxe (Fed + State) for 13 straight years, I was forewarned about the change by reading the reviews before purchasing. Intuit, you've permanently lost a longtime customer. I switched to H&R Block's Deluxe (Fed + State) for less than half the price of TurboTax. The H&R Block software was able to read my TurboTax 2013 files without any problems (Windows 7). Note: Today, I just received an e-mail from Intuit detailing a $25 rebate (with lots of paperwork to get it) for those who have already "paid the price". Sorry, Intuit, that ship has sailed. I've moved on.

title: I would like to thank the Amazon reviewers for emphasizing the valuable ...
content: First of all, I would like to thank the Amazon reviewers for emphasizing the valuable information about the changes made in the feature-tiers of the 2014 TurboTax products. Like most people that have used this product for years, I went straight to the product level that I would usually purchase based on my tax situation - which is the Deluxe level. Unfortunately, I am also one of the 2-4% of Intuit's Turbotax customers affected by this change. Like many that have posted, I have been a long-term user of the TurboTax products all the way back to the days of large packages of floppy discs where the first night's tax prep activity was just loading the software. As part of my regular job I interact with electronics vendors/sales teams almost daily. I've found that direct feedback is sometimes beneficial at the sales level but rarely helpful at the executive level within the companies I dialog with. In 25 years in the electronics industry, I've never seen an executive that made a wrong decision regardless of the amount of negative feedback from customers. Even so, I will summarize my thoughts... - While the feature-set of the TurboTax tiers may have been rearranged to be more consistent within the TurboTax portfolio (online, mobile, etc.), the PC/MAC version is now grossly inconsistent with the feature tiers of the competition. - Intuit appears to be relying on the stickiness of the TurboTax brand with its customers in order to bridge across this transition. The fact that Intuit/TurboTax can cite a 2-4% customer impact clearly means that a study was conducted to understand the financial impact of adjusting the feature tiers and the amount of any financial impact has been "bounded." I would strongly suspect that even the offering of a free upgrade to the Premier edition is part of the "stickiness" plan. - Personally, I can't justify paying $70 for Premier (price as of this writing) versus $35 from a well-established competitor (HRB) for virtually the same feature tier. The TurboTax brand just isn't that sticky for me. I would probably switch even if the competitor's product didn't import the TurboTax data files, but it does so it's an even easier decision. It's ultimately all about the money. All the rest is just pretty words and branding. I'm paying x for a feature set from the competitor and 2x for the basically the same feature set from Intuit. TurboTax has always had a little bit of a price premium through recent years, but 2x is too much. Thanks again to all of the reviewers for getting the word out. Also thanks to the Intuit Exec(s) for pointing out reasons for decisions along with workarounds for those willing to undertake the extra work required to go those paths.

title: like other reviewers
content: I, like other reviewers, was going to purchase the Deluxe version when I saw how many 1 star reviews there were. I now find out that the Deluxe is not what it was in years past. I agree with all of the negative adjectives thrown at Intuit. Face it Intuit. You made a bad business decision. You may ultimately end up with more cash in your coffers but you have alienated a whole lot of previously happy, loyal customers. Despite the fact that I have used TurboTax for the last 10+ years, I will be moving to another product. You must have been listening to Mr. Gruber but the American consumer is not as stupid as you think .

title: Intuit Execs: You may want to check those golden parachutes for holes
content: Thanks to previous reviewers for bringing this to the forefront for those of us who would have not thought twice about continuing our customer loyalty with Turbo Tax Deluxe. I hope some heads roll for this decision at the top to Intuit as double digit market share is sure to be lost for this one. So instead of adding functionality to the platforms where it is missing, the most logical choice is to remove it from the oldest platform? And this decision had nothing to do with making more money? How ignorant do you think we are? Why was this functionality missing from the online and mobile deluxe versions in the first place? H&R Block, here is your chance to shine. You are finally getting your chance with my family and I will encourage my friends to do the same. Maybe this will encourage more people to talk with their congressman/woman to push for a free option from the IRS since we all pay our taxes for such services anyhow (at least those who are using this type of software). Consumers: Today you have the power to vote with your wallet, try anybody but Turbo Tax this year. This will both show Intuit how easy it is to lose customer loyalty, and give a warning signal to other tax software providers who may consider the same misstep.

title: For last 15 years I was using TurboTax Deluxe for ...
content: For last 15 years I was using TurboTax Deluxe for Federal and State. Again this year, without giving a second thought I bought TurboTax Deluxe with one State for doing my 2014 taxes. Afterwards, it came as a surprise that this year TurboTax made a change in deluxe version without informing their loyal customers in that it has no schedules C, D or E. I lost money, but I am planning not to use TurboTax for 2014 taxes. I am going to Amazon.com to buy HR Block software and use it for 2014 taxes as well in future. For me TurboTax is no longer good.

title: Looks like HR Block is going to have a GREAT year
content: Just wanted to let Intuit know they've lost yet another longtime user. Looks like HR Block is going to have a GREAT year! Gotta love when greed gets packaged as "improvement". Hey Intuit... you better hire more csr's because you're going to have a whole lot of dissatisfied customers this year! edit - I've noticed a Intuit VP trying to defend their changes on Amazon, stating it was so necessary and better for everyone and not at all motivated by greed. Say what you like but public perception is everything, you should know that. If you are going to remove features that have been there all along, you should change the name of the product. By keeping it "Deluxe" you are misrepresenting it. Say McDonalds decides to change how they make a Big Mac and make it with only one patty, but then offers an Ultra Big Mac (for twice as much money) with two patties. Do you think people are going to think that the Big Mac has changed? Of course not, they will assume the Ultra has 3 patties or something. Whether it was intentional or not, you made a huge mistake by continuing to use the same name of Deluxe and I would advise you stop with your nonsense justifications and explanations and admit you screwed up.

title: Time to Move On!
content: Came here to get my TurboTax Deluxe and when I see over 1300 negative reviews made me pause. Like most of the reviews have been using TurboTax for years. But it seems each year they raise the price and include less features and the newer features I did not care for. Like most reviewers looks like the time to move on. Its time to vote with your pocket book so I purchased the H&R Block deluxe software for about $35 that will do everything TurboTax 2013 but now they want close to $75 for the same comparable software.

title: The End of a 23 Year Relationship
content: 1991 was the first year I used TurboTax, which was the first program that really illustrated to me the benefits of Windows over DOS! It thought it was so cool that you could click on a number and "drill down" to the underlying schedule. I was hooked. Every since then I have used TT to do my tax return plus those of friends and relatives that covered a wide variety of tax situations. That's twenty-three years altogether. There won't be a twenty-fourth. Intuit has exploited my loyalty and their market position one step two far with their latest product and pricing shenanigans. I'm switching to H&R Block's Tax software. Good riddins Intuit and TurboTax. It was a nice relationship while it lasted, but you've worn out your welcome. I strongly encourage all former users of TurboTax to vote with their dollars and switch to H&R Block's software. I want heads to roll at Intuit. ********** Addendum 1/31/15: I just learned that Intuit has recognized its mistake, is implementing free upgrades for 2014, and has promised to return the features for the 2015 version of TT Deluxe. This doesn't change the fact that it was an incredibly stupid move on Intuit's part. However, I always maintain that ANY organization (or individual) can make a mistake, but the true test of customer service is how they respond to the mistake. Customer loyalty has been to known to INCREASE when a company makes good after a stumble. That said, Intuit's initial response to the mistake was weak and insulting, with a bogus justification for the change instead of admitting the error of the change, but they seem to have finally seen the light and decided they need to do the right thing. So, on the one hand, I want to accept their apology and move on, and continue to use TurboTax. On the other hand, I worry about the huge market position they hold and the potential likelihood of them pulling something like this again in the future. I have to wonder if they would have even thrown us this bone had it not been for the existence of another credible tax software provider: H&R Block. It might be a good idea if enough of us decided to switch to H&R Block, anyway, just to ensure TurboTax always has competition to keep them honest. I look at what's happened to Quicken, which no longer has any decent competition: They foist whatever changes they want on users and we have no recourse other than to stop using personal computer-based financial software if we don't want to pay for their incessant "upgrades" which add nothing but the time it takes to complete anything. What to do, what to do...

title: H&R Block is cheaper, better, and has more forms by far!
content: ZERO stars. Luckily I didn't buy it, switched to H&R Block and saved $40. I hope those involved in this decision to cripple the program so everyone would have to buy Premier are fired. I have read every arrogant comment by this so called VP at TT, that alone was enough to get me to switch. What a joke, I hope their sales tank. By the looks of the reviews he accomplished that. One final note, switch this year. I wouldn't put it past them to make their data files non-transferable to another companies in the near future. You have been warned!

title: Avoid TurboTax, read the reviews BEFORE you buy
content: The other reviews make an abundant case for avoiding TurboTax. I wish I had read them before making my purchase. I've now spent more time dealing with Intuit than I have doing my taxes, and I'm shocked at their behavior. They come across less like a large corporation and more like some fly-by-night scam artist. 1. The original announcement about changes to the product line-up described it all as an enhanced customer experience without giving sufficient detail to evaluate it. I can't find the original to verify as it has been replaced by the "We messed up..." message. 2. The software waits until you have entered as much information as possible before it tells you that an upgrade is necessary to complete your return. In my case, the need for a specific form was triggered by carry-forward info from last years return. The need for an upgrade was known right at the beginning when the prior year return was imported. Did it tell me then - No! Better to have me invest hours in my return before demanding more money to continue. 3. When I called Intuit support to understand why my simple return required an upgrade, they eventually gave me a free upgrade to the Premier version of the product, telling me that the state return is included as in the Deluxe version I originally purchased. It took over an hour on the phone to get the new product downloaded and installed. 4. When I got to the state return, the product would claim that the state download was already installed, then when I tried to start working on it would force another attempt to download it. After another hour on the phone with Intuit support, and after multiple re-installs and reboots, the support person put me on hold and came back to tell me that I need to buy the state download. After I pointed out that I had been told that it's included, and another ten minutes on hold, he tells me that he's sorry but the prior support person had mis-informed me. 5. At that point I had had enough of Intuit and decided to return the product and asked for instructions to do so. He insisted that Intuit only handles returns when the product is purchased directly from them, and that I would have to handle the return with Amazon directly. 6. After trying to handle it via Amazon, only to learn "This item isn't eligible for return", I called Intuit support again and got someone who knew how to initiate the return. After providing the requested information, I was told I'd get an email in 2-3 weeks confirming that the return request was being processed. That means that they won't even acknowledge that I've requested a refund until the end of the 60-day window for requesting a refund! I asked for an email that at least showed that I had requested a refund that day, and was told that would be no problem. I'm still waiting...

title: Bye Bye Bob
content: Bob Meighan, I'm president of a software company (much smaller than yours), but one with 86% of our target market. I achieved that by providing needed service and ever increasing functionality - NOT deleting functionality. I've used Turbotax since it only printed forms in the 1980's. I'm sorry, but you blew it with this ill considered change. And no, I'm NOT going to call you. Bye Bye Bob.

title: the terrible explanations from Intuit aside
content: In the middle of preparing my taxes with the Deluxe version, which I have used for many years to my satisfaction, TurboTax told me I needed to upgrade to the Home and Business version to handle about $150 worth of expenses. The upgrade cost would be $30 according to the Deluxe version. When I followed the links to the online store, I was told the cost was $40. I declined to buy the upgrade not wanting to support Intuit in their false advertising. This morning I called customer support and worked with a new guy who had to keep putting me on hold to talk with his supervisor. Almost 40 minutes into the call he said he was arranging for a $10 discount - simply matching what Intuit was legally required to do. I said that after 40 minutes on the phone, the upgrade should be free. He placed me on hold again to talk with his supervisor. I was disconnected 2 minutes later. I was searching for alternative tax prep solutions when I came across an article in the NYTimes that said "TurboTax is working with unhappy customers âcase by case,â said Ms. Gatlin. Mr. Dworsky of Consumer World said he called Intuit to complain and was offered a free upgrade. He advised others who were unhappy to do the same thing." So, I called customer support again (another 15 minutes on hold) and asked the next, new customer support rep why I had not been offered a free upgrade when I called the first time. She had to check with her supervisor and came back saying that because the first support rep had set me up for a $10 discount, she could do nothing. I asked to speak with her supervisor. After a final 5 minute hold she came back and offered me an additional $5 discount. I hung up. So, Intuit is running a course on how to lose customers with false advertising and making customers jump though hoops just to get the advertised price. Be aware of what you are NOT buying with the deluxe version, the terrible explanations from Intuit aside. Amazon - why NOT provide a zero star option?

title: Lasted longer than my marriage, but ended the same way.
content: My relationship with TurboTax lasted longer than my marriage, but ended with about the same feelings of being cheated and gouged, so sad. I used TurboTax for the first time in 1995 just to see how it would do, compared to an H&R Block office. H&R Block didn't charge a prep fee if your calculations matched theirs. TurboTax had my refund $1 higher than H&R Block so I had to pay a $69 preparation fee + a filing fee. I swore to the H&R Block rep then & there that H&R Block had lost my business forever. I've been a loyal TurboTax user ever since. This year's debacle has ended my 20 year relationship with TurboTax. Firstly, I don't like the sneak attack, changing features to gouge users. In my research, I found that other tax software (namely Tax Cut) was SIGNIFICANTLY cheaper and rated higher by respectable review sites (PC Mag). $35 for TurboTax Deluxe + 15 For TurboTax State OR $12.99 for TaxAct Deluxe + $7 for TaxAct State. So $50 vs $20. It seems that after 20 years, I'm right back at square one with a tax preparer trying to screw me over.

title: I thus find Intuit's attempt to both raise the price and force us to use a more expensive version to be one of the worst of busi
content: I am another who has been a TurboTax user since it's original few years. Since the year-to-year costs of updating TurboTax have clearly been minimal for the last several years, the cost of TurboTax should decrease, not go up. I thus find Intuit's attempt to both raise the price and force us to use a more expensive version to be one of the worst of business practices. I can just imagine the discussion around a conference table as the decision to take these actions was considered. Did anyone consider how it would make us, the users, feel? Did they decide they would get enough new money to make up for the lost customers? Did anyone advise against the decision? Well, I am retired and no longer have a conference table to sit around and make decisions. But I have decided not to ever support a company with such little regard for its long term customers. I find the $25 rebate for sticking with TurboTax insulting. Anyone who is taken in by this has my sympathy. I have switched to TaxACT. I find it easy to use. It costs less. It includes all forms. Anyone considering TurboTax should take a serious look at TaxAct. HR Block's TaxCut is another possibility. TurboTax -- Boo! Boo! Boo!

title: "We've made some changes to TurboTax this year to give you the best possible experience for your specific tax needs
content: This is part of the e-mail that Turbo Tax sent me (as a loyal customer since 2004): "We've made some changes to TurboTax this year to give you the best possible experience for your specific tax needs. Make sure you choose the right product for your tax situation." You see, by forcing me to buy a more expensive version, I will be getting a much better experience. My investments are not too complicated, but I do need to include them on my return. (My H&R Block software just arrived in the mail today.)

title: TurboTax Deluxe has been degraded!
content: It's true. The Deluxe version of TurboTax 2014 has been downgraded severely. No more Schedule C or D or E. Only has Sched. C-EZ, if you are eligible to use it. Intuit, YOU BLEW IT! Not only did you raise the price, but you degraded the product! In order to do my taxes with TurboTax, (like I have for the last 25 years, BTW) I must now pay triple the price I have paid in previous years to get the same functionality. I'm done with TurboTax. Time to try a new tax software.

title: It looks like it is easier to use
content: Almost 2 decades ago I switched from doing my taxes on paper to using TurboTax. I used them every year since then. A couple of years ago, the product started going downhill while the cost was going uphill. After reading the reviews for this year, I made the switch to H&R Block's software. H&R includes the ability to transfer last year's TurboTax information into their software. It looks like it is easier to use, it has more functionality, covers more forms, has free support and is cheaper. Switching away from TurboTax is a no brainer for me.

title: Beware, Bait and Switch! Intuit has decide to destroy it's reputation to scam people!
content: TurboTax Scam 2014! I have been using TurboTax for over 10 years now to prepare my tax paperwork. I purchased TurboTax Deluxe 2014 and while I was using it popped up saying I had to pay an additional $40 to upgrade to the Home and Business. I did not claim or do anything different than I have been for years, but now they have arbitrarily decided to charge us more to do the same thing. Wish I had read the reviews before purchasing, but after over 10 years of using TurboTax I was accustomed to the product and never would have envisioned the changes this year. I will move on to one of the alternatives out there next year.

title: Leaving Turbotax for H&R Block Deluxe
content: No more TurboTax for this long time Deluxe version user. TurboTax has eliminated Schedules D, among other things, from their 2014 Deluxe version (reporting Capital Gains and losses) and I will not pay the substantially higher price to move up to the Premier edition. Providing less for more each year seems to be a trend at Turbo Tax. The H&R Block Deluxe version will do everything TurboTax Deluxe used to do at a much lower price, making it, in my opinion, a much better choice.

title: What Were You Thinking?
content: Good bye TurboTax. It was a good run for us. I was one of your early adopter, loyal customers for over twenty years. I started with your product on floppy disks for heaven sakes. Your greed has now pushed me away. I'll miss you but H&R Block will get my business this year. Netflix got themselves into the same predicament a year or so ago and then quickly re-thought their corporate marketing strategy after customers left in droves. Just wait till your customers who haven't read these reviews get into the middle of their taxes and find out they have to upgrade. Where Netflix had little competition and many of their customers returned, yours' will not. I would love to be a fly on your boardroom wall right now. Update: Well I took the plunge and purchased H&R Block today. It installs easily, is cheaper than TurboTax and seamlessly imports you TT files. For all of you folks like me that were afraid of going to a different tax software after twenty years with Intuit, don't worry there is virtually no learning curve in moving to H&R Block.

title: From all the messages it looks like change to H&R Block is not too hard
content: Thanks for everyone putting in their reviews, specifically the fact that H&R Block is importing data painlessly, and seems to be no harder than TT in doing taxes. Thankfully, did not open the package so Costco will take it in return. Another decades old user switching to H&R Block. Intuit: Please don't add your pompous and condescending message about Change being hard. From all the messages it looks like change to H&R Block is not too hard.

title: Turbotax customer since 1989 - switching to HR Block - thanks for nothing morons
content: Thanks for nothing - Intuit customer since your days in Iowa and have used nothing but TurboTax since 1989 in all of it's various guises. I'm moving to HR Block as at least they understand that they're selling a glorified spreadsheet with a help function . . . .

title: Eighteen years of using TurboTax to file my Federal Taxes ...
content: Eighteen years of using TurboTax to file my Federal Taxes. I bought TurboTax Deluxe again this year as usual. Now surprise, they have crippled Deluxe to not work with Schedule C. The website says Schedule C is included and I checked before purchase but when running the software the extortion message pops up that I will not be able to eFile my return as prepared without a $40 upgrade. They will let me print and file a paper copy only. Ridiculous. My "small business" has net profits of $4000 annually so they want to extort 1% of my profit after I've purchased the software, after the return is prepared, for the privilege of eFiling. This is the last straw. Misleading that Schedule C is included, extorting paying customers after return is prepared.

title: Another "EX" Turbo user.
content: I'm another ex loyal customer of Turbotax who almost got burned. Thanks to those who gave the one star rating. I wasn't even going to look at the ratings since TT has always been good--the software version that is, not the online, that was a headache a few years ago--never again. Just as I was about to click the buy button I noticed the low star rating and decided to read some of the reviews--glad I did. I need the schedule D and with broker data import. I think what really frosts people is not the fact that the price went up--it's the sneaky way that unsuspecting buyers were duped into buying what they thought was their normal product and then they were forced to cough up another 30 bucks or lose their entire investment. This is no way to do business and it will lose a lot of customers--including me. Had they merely increased the cost by ten bucks nobody would have cared--most everything goes up a little.. I just downloaded the less expensive H & R Block program and did a preliminary mockup of my 2014 return in minutes---very smooth, didn't have to read any directions. It didn't install any other unwanted programs. It imported by 2013 Turbotax information perfectly--I didn't even have to tell it where to fiind it. It seemed very easy to pick and choose what sections to fill out and which to skip. I like it. Saved me $50 too--that I really like.

title: DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY THIS YEAR
content: I've been using Turbo Tax for years and was so happy -- UNTIL THIS YEAR. I don't know what they did to change the program, but I had to pay an additional $30 to upgrade the package in order to enter my mortgage interest. Even though Turbo Tax says it will refund me $25, I'm still not happy with the program. It used to be so user-friendly -- not anymore. This is the first time, I've had to struggle to find places in the form for my entries. It seems that the people at Turbo Tax have streamlined the program to its bare bones. I definitely regret this purchase. It's definitely not worth the price I paid -- I should have invested far less and downloaded the HR Block software.

title: Greed, the undoing of our great country!
content: Yep no schedule C or D equals no turbo tax. I have been using turbo tax since 1994 and I just bought H&R blocks software for 2014 taxes. Quite tired of supporting corporate greed and the knitting of golden parachutes. Best part is that I bought H&R block deluxe version from Amazon for $28.88, tax included!

title: Bye Bye TurboTax
content: No Schedule D? That's insane. Add me to the list of long time TurboTax users (in my case, since the early 90s) that will make the switch to H&R Block this year. The thing is, I don't think Intuit really cares about us. They know that some be upset, some will defect, others will spend the extra $$$ for the Premier version, and by next year the storm will be over and they'll be a new crop of the gullible. Make no mistake: this was a clearly calculated move on their part.

title: As a CPA, I find it a bit disingenuous ...
content: As a CPA, I find it a bit disingenuous of Intuit to play this off as comparative issue. When the IRS is actively encouraging e-file, allowing the previously included forms to be filled out and then blocking transmission is rotten in my book. I don't understand how this isn't a bait and switch tactic.... customer is 90% done with return, finds he can't finish until he upgrades for additional expense = doesn't want to spend additional funds (and more importantly time invested in prep) to switch at that point, must purchase upgrade.

title: I'm sad that Intuit has decided to be so dishonest
content: Please go elsewhere for your taxes, I used the online version, what a rip off. I'm sad that Intuit has decided to be so dishonest... You have to go through all the work to enter your data before you are automatically charged more.. No option to downgrade...in fact I thought I had done something wrong and spent even more time trying to unwind my return. Gave up and submitted my return. I paid more in fees than my return..BS.. Next time I will use TaxAct

title: If you were stupid like me
content: In fact, DELUXE no longer supports Schedules C, D or E. A loyal TT user since 2004, I have had it with Intuit's bait & switch practices. The details of this not-so-obvious downgrade can be found in many of the other reviews. If you were stupid like me, and bought TT 2014, email proof of purchase to SwitchtoBlock@hrblock.com and Block will presumably send you for free what you thought you were getting from Intuit.

title: I'll switch to a competitive product
content: I've bought and used TurboTax every year for as long as I can remember. I got the Premier version a time or two, but generally used Deluxe, and that did a great job. Looks like the party is over. If Deluxe doesn't have schedule D, I'm getting a competitive product this year. Intuit, if you're listening, you have till probably the end of January to fix this before I switch to a competitor's product.

title: Phew - what a stinker. Intuit's bait-and-switch on 2014 ...
content: Phew - what a stinker. Intuit's bait-and-switch on 2014 Turbo Tax is so self defeating, it boggles the mind. A corporate decision right up there with "We'll make the computer hardware - but not the software." They've alienated their customer base is so extensively, it should be taught in MBA Program lectures on 'What were they thinking when they killed their company?'

title: Boycott Intuit TurboTax
content: TurboTax has lost me as a customer. Companies now work more on how to increase cost/price per transaction. Like how to get shoppers to spend more per visit. We are their "Product". A nice MBA term. They took out schedule D and make you spend $30 more for the version that includes it. We all need to stop doing business with crooks.

title: Just like grocery store items where the package gets reduced from ...
content: Just like grocery store items where the package gets reduced from 16 oz to 14 oz, for the same price, and the packaging says "New and Improved!", Turbotax's decision to remove Schedules C-F from the Deluxe version in the name of "reducing customer confusion" has simply caused this 22+ year loyal TurboTax user to look elsewhere this year!

title: Goodbye Intuit
content: Wow. I've been using TurboTax since the floppy disk days. The past few years have been very disappointing. I'm glad to see the online review reactions. Maybe Intuit will realize that poking loyal customers in the eye once a year is a bad idea. I just bought and downloaded HR Block tax software from Amazon. Goodbye Intuit.

title: Think Twice About Purchasing Turbotax This Year
content: So glad I read the reviews. After being a TT user since 1998 and now finding out I can no longer use the Deluxe edition because the interview process is no longer included for some of the forms I need will mandate a change to another software program. Too bad Intuit, you've lost a very loyal customer.

title: NOT for Minnesotans!!!
content: Don't buy this product. Minnesota State Taxes will NOT process Turbo Tax processed returns! They have been hacked. They apparently spent all last year figuring out ways to reap stockholder benefits by bamboozling their customer base and failed to monitor the single most essential element in tax filing: security. Congratulations, TT. I found this out AFTER I used your product to file my daughter's tax return! Consider me an HR Block Convert. Utterly disgusted.....<:-(

title: No More
content: So glad I peeked inside before buying this year's Deluxe version. Funny, I'm a retired CPA and former QuickBooks Pro Advisor. The same disappearing functions happened in QuickBooks and Quicken too. The next Quicken upgrade I buy looks like it will cost about $100. The last one (2012) was $35 including tax. Ouch. As a CPA with some actual tax preparation experience, I was starting to have some trouble with the Turbo Tax interface, forcing me into ways of doing things that weren't always quite what I would have wanted or expected. For me, I think it's probably best that Intuit forced the issue for me to move on. Good-bye Bob. Hello H&R Tax Software.

title: Not what I expected--very disappointed.
content: I am going to ask for my money back. H&R Block software includes all the schedules I need for less than half the price of Turbo Tax. I don't know why Intuit dropped those schedules when they were there last year. Oh, maybe they wanted to force you to buy the premier version. That version currently costs $75 on Amazon.H&R Block Deluxe is only $34. Both include state forms. Too bad, I was hoping to try a different tax program this year. I'm just not willing to pay $75 for the premium version. $35-40 would be a much more reasonable price.

title: TT wonder how many customers you've lost?
content: I, like many others, have purchased TT for many previous years and am soooo disappointed with TT (Intuit) with their greed and sly attempt to force customers into adding more expense on them. After receiving such a BIG black-eye from customers reviews here and else where, they sort-of were willing to upgrade to next level, IF CUSTOMERS PHONED TT CUSTOMER SUPPORT, COMPLAIN AND THEN WERE UPGRADED. I received a corporate reason e-mail today 2015_02_06 from TT, basically stating that "Oops" we got caught being greedy and will refund $25.00 to customers who put-out extra for upgrading and will allow those customers preparing taxes to return to previous years of good tax preparing experiences, by not forcing customers to purchase the upgrade. My reply to this upper-management sly attempt of greed, is purchasing H&R Block and will in the future years. H&R Block is less $ than TT, generally, so THANK YOU TT for making me save money, by opening my eyes, not automatically returning to my usual tax software.

title: Beware 'returning deluxe customers' is misleading and requirements not listed! Don't buy if you need stocks/investments
content: Contrary to the large banners you see on Amazon about being able to upgrade from Deluxe to Premier if you need it... there are extra conditions NOT DISCLOSED in the comments here from Intuit or their big video from the CEO in what 'returning Deluxe' customers really means. You must have filed with turbotax and imported the file with 2013 explictly. The REAL requirements "Valid for customers who filed their 2013 taxes with TurboTax Deluxe (CD or download), completed prior year data transfer this year, and encounter an upgrade to either 2014 TurboTax Premier or 2014 TurboTax Home & Business (CD or download)" So it's not 'returning' customers it's for 2013 CD/download customers ONLY. In my case, I had not filed with 2013 turbotax due to complications I was not comfortable with and went to a CPA instead. 15 years+ with Turbotax is not a 'returning customer' in their eyes, and even though they claim they will change the software for NEXT year.. they still opt to leave this trap in for 2014. Completely unacceptable. Thank god Amazon stood behind their customer for me and allowed me to cancel this order.

title: Thankfully there are other options available...a.k.a. the competition.
content: Wow...I'm glad I spent the time to read through many of these reviews. I've been a user since 1997, growing increasingly annoyed with each year's release, and am now unwilling to continue using their product. From the backhanded methods of trying to push you to more expensive versions, to the continual focus on the rebate $$$ they are "helping" you to find, culminating with this years' Schedule changes, leave me unable to trust them with my business or personal details. Even their website appears to have fake reviews pumping non-descript high ratings. Thankfully there are other options available...a.k.a. the competition. ********* Update to review - I purchased H&R Block Deluxe on 12/23 and can immediately say I'm sold. Much more straightforward interface, no annoying plugs for upgrading, no "rebate mania", better price/value. It imported all my prior TT data. TTQuicken (Intuit) had better heed the backlash to their methods. Switching to the competition was quite easy...and I held out for years, expecting them to take feedback seriously.

title: The power of the consumer!
content: I have been disgruntled in the past by Intuit's business practices. Having inadvertently signed up for "automatic renewal" in 2012, I was surprised when my account was debited in AUGUST for the new software - no email, no phone call, no warning. When I tried to cancel the subscription to the automatic renewal, there was a limited time window to do so. All in all, I felt like I had been "taken" and used it again (after I got off automatic renewal and provided NO information with my purchase) only because I had the history of all the years I used Turbo Tax. After reading about the C-D schedule mess and the manufacturer's responses to reviews on this site, I went out on a limb and purchased H&R Block software. I started working with it yesterday. The Turbo Tax returns were imported without any issue and I found the software to be straight forward and user friendly and MUCH cheaper. So goodbye Turbo Tax and shady business practices! You really can't fool all of the people all of the time...

title: Insult to injury
content: I won't repeat the original issue with TurboTax. Plenty here have explained it well. The latest is that Intuit is storing SSN numbers of all of their previous customers, even desktop users. This is completely unacceptable, and dangerous. I used the desktop version to keep my personal information off the internet. Now I find out they have captured my sensitive information and it is stored online, on their servers, susceptible to hackers worldwide. I think a class action lawsuit is in order. We see Intuit employees here in the reviews attempting damage control on their underhanded pricing... How will they handle the latest (and most egregious) misstep? For me, they should delete my personal info. Beyond that, I will never spend another dime with Intuit.

title: What's Deluxe??
content: What's Deluxe about a product that a doesn't support a simple capital gain, How about Basic, oh That's been used.. I have been a TurboTax user since the early 1990's but the recent changes are ridiculous. Anyone that has any mutual funds is going to need schedule D at some point. The deluxe product is a JOKE, a simple case of a greedy company trying to increase revenues by extorting money from their unaware customer base!!

title: Dumb move by Intuit
content: I will be looking at TaxCut this year. Intuit has totally ruined a 10+ love affair that I had with TurboTax due to removing some critical forms from the Deluxe (and even the Premier) version. I use Schedule F and now I have to buy the Business version to do my taxes using TurboTax. Due to the changes Intuit chose to make, I will be willing to pay just as much for TaxCut just on principle.

title: Goodbye TurboTax! Won't be back!
content: I purchased TurboTax deluxe software at a retailer just like I have for the past 12 years. I did not break the seal or open the case so I will be returning it to the retailer. I do not need the missing forms for my tax situation but I am standing in solidarity with those who do need these forms. I paid the same price for a watered down version of the software I have used for many years. On top of that, my state (MN) has stopped accepting e-files prepared with TurboTax. Enough is enough. I am so completely sick of corporate arrogance and greed, that Intuit will never again get even a single nickle of my money, no matter how much they grovel and issue sappy apologies. How I long for the days of businesses truly valuing their customers and treating them right no matter the bottom line. I have used H&R Block software many years ago and was plenty satisfied with it. They will now have a returning and longterm customer for as long as they treat me right. Goodbye TurboTax!

title: May the seeds of greed bear bitter fruit.
content: Like numerous other _former_ Turbo Tax users, I find Intuit's greed here to be disturbing. The company's responses are a mix of disingenuousness (the old product lineup was confusing), belittling (only 2-4% of users are affected), greasing the squeaky wheel (we'll give you an upgrade if you call and complain loudly enough), non-answers (you can still use schedules C, D, and E -- but then it won't error check your return, and you'll have to paper file), and general irrelevance (you can call one of our customer service reps who will be happy to recommend what version you should get). Had the immediate response been "yes, we see that we messed up really badly; we will give everyone who bought a copy of Deluxe an upgrade, no questions asked, we'll sell the top of the line product for the Deluxe price, and we've learned our lesson and will do right by our customers in the future", this might have blown over. Now? No way. I have posted a link to this review page to Facebook, where I have quite a few friends and followers whom I don't want to see be shabbily treated. That will probably cost Intuit more sales, not just people who will now realize that the old mainstay Deluxe is not the right product, but also people who might not have been directly affected but whose sense of honor and propriety is outraged by such sharp practice. I can't say for certain, but if the company is correct that only 2-4% of its customers are affected, I expect that the loss of sales will greatly outweigh the incremental revenue from higher prices. I certainly hope that that is the case. And by the way, Mr. Meighan, if you were concerned about inconsistencies in your product line, you could have chosen to upgrade the functionality of your online and mobile products to match those of the desktop rather than the other way around. And if the bottom line really was the bottom line (as you have implied with your comment about "duty to shareholders"), you could have raised the prices by 5-10% across the board with at most mild grumbling. Yes, I am aware that you would probably offer me a free upgrade if I took the trouble to call, since I could prove that I'm a returning customer. But that would require extra effort on my part and would simply reward your business practice, which I am not willing to do.

title: Tried to sneak a price increase in version changes and got caught - is very sorry and wants to make up. Too late for me.
content: Stuck with Turbotax through the DRM debacle (didn't have options) but when I found that I would have to pay through the nose to handle stock sales (after having to do research), I decided to try H&R block. It was much cheaper and after installing it and going through the process, I found it to be a non-issue to make the switch. I only use turbotax once a year so its always a learning curve to use the software and found that getting used to the H&R block's interface was not any more difficult than the yearly change in Turbotax. Matter of fact I found it intuitive and easy to navigate. Imports worked exactly like they did in Turbotax. While you can now work through the process with Turbotax to get a free upgrade to the version that should never have cost more in the first place, I do not understand why anyone would do it.

title: Good Job, Turbo-Tax, you've lost a twenty year customer
content: I'm certainly glad I read the online reviews, and thanks to LinkedIn for posting the CEO's "Letter of Apology", one of the most thinly disguised, cynical attempts to justify corporate greed I've ever witnessed. I've been a Turbo Tax User for nearly twenty years, and have been one of their most ardent, vocal fans. Having a great deal of experience in software development, I've often used Turbo Tax (as often as a few days ago) as a prime example of a well-constructed software application that uses an intuitive user interface and workflow to provide an excellent customer experience. While I've experienced a few glitches over the years, I appreciated that they were fixed quickly, and overall, my semi-complex filing requirements were met with a relatively small amount of effort. Well, you lost me with this maneuver, Intuit. Your claim that you were simply trying "to align our desktop, online and mobile versions to deliver faster innovation and improved experiences for all customers" by removing Schedules C, D, E, and F doesn't pass my "sniff test". Offering a single, one-time $25 rebate after I file electronically this year if I've already purchased the software, and filed in 2013 using Turbo Tax Deluxe?!!? I don't mean to sound catty, but that's just PATHETIC. I hope the decision maker in this is fired, regardless of position and stature, and I hope this decision is considered a "black swan" when you look back.

title: Don't buy this product. You will regret it!
content: This product is not the complete 'Deluxe' version that use to support all the schedules that a joint filer would require. Using this product requires additional fees in order to complete the return. In addition, recent developments at the Intuit website raises questions about the security of the system and possible vulnerabilities for identity theft. Lastly, the the softwar eperformacne of this program is very poor. Expct long launch times, lengthy software updates times and very slow response. I am sofware developer and have a high-end PC and still the prgram response is painfully slow. After 20 year of using Turbo Tax I'm done! Your unbridled greed and incompetance deserves to be showcased for all to see.

title: Fool me once (DRM in 2003, I believe) - shame on you, but you are fooling us again - NO MORE
content: That's it! I cant and wont take this anymore. I've been Turbo Tax/Intuit user since late 90s but this latest "for the sake of consistency" underhanded move by TT removing schedules and forms and subsequently forcing users to upgrade for more money - that's just too much!!! This will be my last year purchasing TT but only so I can compare the refund amount to H&R and TaxAct. I guess comparison all 3 would cost me a bit more and take a bit, quite a bit, more time - but I'm willing to invest my money and time to find a suitable alternative. That's it Turbo Tax - you've done it, no more business from me! Fool me once - shame on you, but fool me twice.... I remember previous DRM debacle when Intuit backpedaled similar to this year. I also despise their Quicken piece of s**** crap but lack of alternative FORCES me to stay with them. How I wish Microsoft would resurrect their MS Money or someone else would come up with semi decent money management software. No more Turbo Tax, no more. Edit 1: for all those who already purchased Turbo Tax Delux, H&R Block offers their Delux for free: http://newsroom.hrblock.com/hr-block-offers-free-software-turbotax-users/

title: Intuit Has Shunned Their Long-Term Loyal Customers!
content: I have been a loyal TurboTax user since the mid 90's but have now been forced to switch. Even though I had 100's of stock transactions I have always been able to use TurboTax Basic to do my taxes, not needing all of the bells and whistles of the other versions. Now it would cost $90 because I would have to buy the Premiere edition. They have destroyed the trust of their loyal customers with a single stupid marketing strategy that must have been approved by a committee of clowns! Kudos to all of the negative TurboTax reviewers to alert the public of this Intuit scam. Keeping others from learning that they now have purchased the wrong product in the middle of trying to finish their taxes. The dark side of me hopes that Intuit learns its lesson by losing its carefully built market share to H&R Block. Apparently they must relearn the importance of customer loyalty and not scamming the very people that have supported them for decades. A rousing applause for H&R Block for not taking advantage of TurboTax's misguided and deceptive marketing by increasing their pricing. But, in fact offering a 50% discount (Jan 2nd only) on the Deluxe version which still supports schedule D and direct access to the forms! All for $22!

title: Thank you for screwing up so bad! H&R Deluxe is now Free for those who switch!
content: . ** Update Feb 1, 2015: I just got my 100% free copy of H&R Block Deluxe Federal + State 2014. It's for anybody who used TurboTax in 2013 and wants to switch. You just send them an email with your 2013 invoice or product key. Google "H&R Block Giving Free Tax Software to Disgruntled TurboTax Users" to see if their offer is still open and the correct email address to use. ** This year TurboTax Deluxe has removed support for Schedules C and D. (You can still fill in the forms in the software and file your return on paper if you want.) I might give it 2-stars, except I just got their "We're sorry and we want to make it right" letter chocked full of weasel-talk. Instead of being honest about why they removed support for Schedules C and D, they say: "However, as new online and mobile technologies emerged, our products, and the tax scope and features they included, began to differ, leading to customer confusion. These differences also impeded our ability to introduce new innovations across our entire product line." In essence, "we did this to avoid confusion and help us be more innovative." Right.

title: TurboTax has erroneously classified customers by the schedules they need
content: Thank you for the heads up. We have used Turbo Tax for years, but will no longer. They know they have angry customers and are offering a $25 discount this year only. Not much help. We must file Schedule C to deduct continuing education expenses. We had a no change audit by the IRS and were told to move continuing education expenses to Schedule C. That moves us to a higher software category. We have no home business. We also have a tree farm which does not require farming, but must be filed on Schedule F. There are no crops to sell, no employees, and no need to do anything yet. We will harvest trees in 50 years. Because we need the extra schedules even though there is no income associated with them, TurboTax has decided that we are farmers and that we have a business. They think we need all the other options that would be needed if we indeed did have a business or farmed. We have only expenses, not income and they must be filed on these additional schedules. Removing these schedules is a problem. We have no need to do the extra things these higher level products provide. All we want to do is manually enter our expenses. Restricting the tax forms is what is angering customers. TurboTax should know that just because a customer needs a particular schedule, it doesn't mean they can be classified as having a business or being a farmer or whatever else. I sympathize with the anger and there is no way to justify what TurboTax has done. Fortunately, there are alternatives. Thank you all for the suggestions

title: Once again the folks who brought you Turbo Tax decided to quietly annoy their loyal customers by making a questionable decision
content: Let me start out by saying that Intuit destroyed this years version of Turbo Tax. If you don't want to have Intuit electronically file your State return, Turbo Tax Deluxe 2014 Federal and State contains errors that prevents it from generating a usable copy of my Ohio state tax return that can be filed by mail. Once again the folks who brought you Turbo Tax decided to quietly annoy their loyal customers by making a questionable decision to alter their product in a detrimental way. Many years ago it was adding copy protection that only ended up interfering with their customers ability to install the product. This time it was to quietly remove functionality from the program without telling anyone. This was followed by an unapologetic apology, that was followed by an apology for the apology, stating they would return Turbo Tax back to its original state. Unfortunately, in this change in design, and quick hustle to change back , they broke what used to be a robust and reliable program. Here are some images that show my experience with Turbo Tax Deluxe 2014. 1. After downloading the Turbo Tax Installer and running it, Turbo Tax said I had to uninstall a previous version. The first picture shows the crash that followed this operation. 2. Next I re-ran the downloader. This time Turbo Tax continued with the install, but said I was installing the Basic version. 3. After completing my tax return, I tried to print copies of my returns for my records. This is what the State form looked like. It was watermarked with huge words saying the tax form was not final. How could it be not final when I had already completed my return and submitted the forms electronically. 4. Lastly, Turbo Tax never actually generated an Ohio State form that looks like the Ohio tax document so I could mail in my tax return. What it did do was regenerate the Federal 1040 form along with my other state documents, even though I only had the State form selection checked when I told it to create a preview copy of my Ohio tax return. With all these managerial and software design mistakes, Turbo Tax has plummeted from being the flagship Tax Preparation software, to something I'd be ashamed to offer people as a free-ware program.

title: From "Buy" to "Bye-Bye" TurboTax in one simple lesson
content: I've been a satisfied, loyal customer of TurboTax for the past 2 decades. But I don't feel that this year's sneak attack on TT Deluxe users was a simple mistake. It feels like an intentional, cynical, manipulative corporate attempt to raise revenues without admitting to raising prices. The vacillating, flip-flopping attempts at justification and apology feel like the insincere (and in some cases financially insufficient) products of some crisis-management consultant. Fortunately, I was able to take advantage of HR Block's kind (and savvy) offer of a free replacement program, which I hope will become my regular program, presuming it performs equivalently this year (and so far it looks good -- easy and quick installation with no problem importing my 2013 TurboTax info). I thought all retailers knew that it is far cheaper to retain an existing customer than to attract a new replacement customer -- I guess the TurboTax folks were absent from class the day they taught that in Business School.

title: Good luck upgrading
content: Despite the negative reviews I purchased TurboTax Deluxe because I am a loyal customer and it appeared to me that Turbo Tax had taken the necessary steps to correct the changes in the product and provide refunds to those that already made purchases. According to Amazon and to Turbotax a free upgrade to Premier is available for customers that used Deluxe last year and it is available online after February 7th. I purchased Deluxe, got to the section that asked for my K-1 information, Turbo Tax indicated that I qualified for a free upgrade to Premier, and that's where the fun began. After repeated unsuccessful attempts to upgrade online and receiving the message, "We're having trouble processing your request online," I decided to call the 800# provided. After 26 minutes of waiting hold, I gave up. So now I'm stuck in limbo... I can't file my return because the software won't allow me to enter the information from K-1 and I can't upgrade to Premier because it doesn't work online and no one will pickup the phone when I call. Then I tried to contact customer service online and it was suggested that I call customer service and the wait time is "less than 3 hours." Are you kidding me!

title: Turbo Tax is Arogant, Greedy and Naive
content: Don't let TurboTax fool you. They are hoping they got you hooked. Imagine my surprise when I was using TT Basic and after downloading brokerage data I get a message on the screen saying I need to spend $70 more dollars to upgrade to the Premier version to process Schedule D information. I don't mind spending a few more bucks each year for the consistency but not $70 dollars. Sorry TT but you have lost a long time valued customer. If you were't so greedy I would be staying with you for many years to come but not now. HR Block is offering a free download of their software when you show evidence of purchasing TT. When you think you have locked in your customer and you don't look over your shoulder for the competition than you are just arogant (and naive).

title: Switched to HR Block because of lost functionality
content: I was very disappointed after reading other reviews that TT Deluxe no longer accommodates Schedule D investment income. I have been a loyal TT user since the 90s and now feel slapped in the face. It's ridiculous to force loyal customers to pay an extra $20 to upgrade to the Premier version to make up lost functionality from the Deluxe version. As such, I have decided to switch to HR Block Deluxe to complete my 2014 personal return. And it's $10 cheaper - bonus! I hate to leave you TT after being faithful to you for all these years, but you lost my trust. Bob Meighan, VP TurboTax, it appears you lost a lot of other customers this year too. This was a bad business decision. Lessons learned!

title: Beware the Reduced Functionality
content: Thanks to the warnings of many reviewers, I returned my 2014 TurboTax Deluxe unopened to Costco. I, too, have used TurboTax forever, but went out and got my first H&R Block product. Couldn't see paying more for less. I, too, feel it was reasonable to expect the new tax year's product to have at least the SAME functionality, without having to read the small print to find out the product had been degraded.

title: Really a stupid move and even dumber explanation and fixes
content: I won't repeat what the other thousands of irate customers have said. I will say, however, that the first "we're sorry" e mail from TT was one of the stupidest explanations and half-a@@ apology I have ever read! It was poorly written and didn't even read like it was written by a college graduate. Now we get yet another "we get it" e mail. Nothing short of offering the Business Version for the price of the Deluxe will work for me. I do not want to start the flawed Deluxe just to get prodded with some hastily inserted "free upgrade." Give me the Upgrade Version in the first place or I'm going to H&R Block. Over the past 15 years I have had growing concerns over the rising costs of the "free" State Version and now am hearing about security concerns. Time to move on. Someone at the top deserves to be fired over this for sure.

title: New Coke? Netflix plan split and price hike? Add Intuit 2014 Tax Products to the list.
content: Our family has used TurboTax for more than the past decade to complete federal tax filings. However, in the tradition of such wonderful corporate decisionmaking as that which resulted in the "NEW COKE" and Netflix's gambit splitting online access from DVD rental plans and hiking the prices, Intuit has jumped the shark this year. The heavy hand with which Intuit browbeat customers with promotional offers during tax filing has come out of the glove; this year the company eliminated various core features in the midlevel tiers of their products, effectively jacking the prices up significantly. This is a company that has taken its loyal customers for granted. This guy won't be returning to TurboTax this year. After Intuit's smack in the face, it's time to give a competing product a chance.

title: Do your homework BEFORE buying 2014 Turbo Tax Deluxe - you may be surprised what you DON'T get when you prepare your return
content: I have been buying Turbo Tax programs for many years (over 20) but I'm moving to H&R Block for 2014's tax return. Intuit (the company that makes Turbo Tax) must think their customers are idiots. TT Deluxe has been great for years but this year I would have had to move up to "Premier" ($70) to get Sch D & Sch E (which are 2 very common forms). Then after a little more researching I found out that I would have to move up to "Home & Business" ($80) to get Sch. C. Instead, I'm making the switch to H&R Block Deluxe and getting all that for only $34 (a savings of about $46 as compared to TT). Turbo Tax must be praying that their returning customers don't do their homework and then when they realize that they need a form they'll be a pop up saying that for an extra $$ they'll move your version up. By that point they're betting that you won't want to start over and will pay up. Thanks to all the reviews on Amazon I looked into it and realized I don't need to be price gouged by Intuit. I've read/heard good things about H&R Block's tax software for years so this year might as well be the one to give it a try. I hope Intuit gets the message that their customers have other options.

title: Keeps getting worse year after year and now it's at the lowest point ever.
content: Intuit just keeps getting worse year after year. This is the first year I could not "import" my W-2 electronically from my employer because they are not a "Partner" as defined with Intuit, i.e. they do not "Pay" Intuit their greedy corporate license fees to transmit that secured personal data electronically and thus defeats the ENTIRE purpose for using their software when I now have to wait for mailed hard copies of my W-2 forms to be delivered by mail and enter all the information manually. Last year their software was buggy with mathematical discrepancies that even their CEO flat out denied (lied) in his desperate act of corporate Damage Control. This was finally the straw that broke the camel's back. Going over to H&R Block and I suggest others do the same and no longer support this greedy monopolistic corporation.

title: Gone to H&R Block. Not coming back.
content: I have a different complaint from many others here. I use TurboTax online and up until this year Intuit offered a Basic version that let me file my simple 1040 with itemized deductions for $20. This option is now gone and I have to use the Deluxe version for $35. As is the case for many others, I've used TurboTax for 20 years (since 1995) and would not normally bother looking at alternatives. However, given Intuit's money grab this year, I went ahead and re-did my taxes on the H&R Block site (online product). It was actually easier than TurboTax, in that they determined in advance that I didn't qualify for things like a tuition credit based on my income. TurboTax made me fill out all of the information before telling me I didn't qualify. More importantly, H&R Block is $20. Sorry Intuit. I know you realize you've messed up and are reversing course but it's too late. I'm gone.

title: Don't waste your money on worthless state downloads
content: Don't waste the $10 to get the state download unless you want to wait another month to be able to use it. I bought this download Jan 9, knowing I couldn't e-file my federal return until the 20th, but I expected to be able to at least print out my federal and state forms so that I could mail my state return in right away. Instead I found out today that the state forms will not have the DO NOT FILE watermark removed from them until February 20th! Instead of waiting another month to file, I went to the Dept of Revenue website for my state, downloaded the forms, and completed them by hand. They went out in today's post and I will have my refund before Intuit bothers to release the state forms.

title: I'll give you an upgrade....
content: I've had to "upgrade" my TT Deluxe twice now to get the same functionality as last year. Cost $40. What's worse, after every upgrade, TT forces me to "review" all my previous entries, adding to the time it takes to complete my taxes. My next upgrade will be to H & R Block.

title: Comical fiasco
content: Since this has been a popular place for TurboTax review, I'll recount my comical fiasco - Upon learning the need to switch to TurboTax Premier this year after using Deluxe for 17 years, I ordered TT Premier CD at Intuit website (not Amazon) on 1/25. Order Conformation email indicated the shipping date of 1/27 - 1/29. Received an email notification on 1/30 about a delay, new shipping date is "2 - 14 days from today", and "If you used a credit card, we won't charge your card until your item(s) ship. If you prefer, you can cancel your order at no cost to you by calling a customer service representative at 1-800-4-INTUIT (1-800-446-8848)." Called the 800 number to cancel, was told the following regarding this order: 1. The ordered product has been changed from CD to download, even though the Order Confirmation email clearly stated "TurboTax Premier 2014 CD for Windows and Mac" ; 2. There was one status showing the product was shipped on 1/29, even though the delay notification email was send on 1/30; 3. Current status of the order shows Backorder; 4. Due to the Backorder status, the order can not be cancelled. I'll need to wait for the order to be processed, and return for refund.
