Your reply is a weasel word infested, banal piece. It says nothing other than "change is challenging." Not all change is, you two. But what you did isn't just change -- it's strong-arming - it's robbery. Hey folks, you did hear Intuit top execs got a nearly 2x raise last year? THIS IS HOW THEY PAID FOR IT! Sincerely yours, An ex-TT user

title: Long time Turbotax user, time to move on from the greed.
content: Moving on. To much profit for you to take more money every year. Every year I have paid the premium to buy your software and last year the charges kept coming even after the purchase. To much people. Time to give the competition a look over.

title: A questionable move from the Intuit Sales Prevention team...
content: After buying the Deluxe version for years and it covering my needs,I find this year when I purchased and opened the Deluxe version that they had removed the portion where I can file my Sch. C for my small Sole Proprietor business and instead is forcing me to upgrade to the Premier version for only twice the price. This is a pretty sneaky way to slip this in, but in the consumer world I guess it is "buyer beware". I am a registered Intuit TurboTax user, so it would have been nice to get an advisory e-mail that the product I had used in the past was being stripped of features but my guess is Intuit preferred to try to slip this one in once they had my money for the product I had bought for years assuming it would do the job it always has. Needless to say, they got me this year but I will be converting to a competitive product for my 2015 taxes. Nice customer retention move, Intuit!

title: TurboTax turbo'd right into terribleness
content: I have used (*ahem* Use to use) TurboTax (free edition) for decades and never had a problem with it, till this last year when I bought the edition to do this promotion for the Amazon gift card. My refund was held up and I didn't receive it until October!!! And? They never added their 10 percent for the gift card!!! Never before have I had a worse refund experience. TurboTax is going downhill, very fast. I will never spend another dime on TurboTax and no longer will Ever recommend them. What use to be a quality product, is now simply another cheapened product with higher prices so their owners can make increasing profit while skrewing over the people.

title: Thanks fellow reviewers
content: Thanks to the early reviews here I discovered a week ago that TT Deluxe will no longer work for me. I have since followed the online discussions, read the news reports, explored the alternative programs & considered the âoffersâ Intuit has made to âfixâ things with longtime customers like myself. Most of all I have watched the way they have reacted to this situation. Their response reeks of âwe donât careâ. It has not been an easy decision for me due to the comfort level I had reached using TT over the years, however I realized I have lost my trust in TurboTax & am very uncomfortable supporting the kind of corporation it seems to have become. I have ordered H&R Block software mostly out of principal & already feel better.

title: Deluxe isn't deluxe anymore.
content: Grrr... TurboTax is now a business school example of what not to do. I've used Deluxe for years and that's what I bought this year. But Deluxe isn't what it was. Nope. There are changes and I'm one of the customers who simply assumed Deluxe would be the same this year too. The reviews here have made this obvious, but I didn't read them when I was buying in a store. I simply threw the Deluxe version into my cart and expected TurboTax to maintain its continuity. Now I'm reading reviews about Intuit's sneaky practices that have caused a fairly large customer backlash. I didn't think I'd need to read reviews for a product I've used reliably for 20 years. H&R Block can hardly believe their luck and are offering free software to help with the transition away from Intuit. I'm going to take H&R Block's offer and see how it compares.

title: "Deluxe" is unusable for almost EVERYONE. DO not let Turbotax/Intuit get away with it. Use H&R Block or other option.
content: I have loyally used Turbo Tax for almost as long as its been in existence, but this is the last year! I purchased and installed the deluxe version as I have every year, only to then learn I had to pay an extra $30 to upgrade to "Premier" to handle basic investments. TOTALLY UNACCEPTABLE. Since when would standard investments not be included in a "DELUXE" package! Never ever again will I recommend this product, and I will be telling everyone within ear shot to NOT go near the product or company anymore. I feel like a fool as I had convinced many friends over the year of the benefits of this product. A $25 "rebate" to "make up for it" is ridiculous and does nothing to remove the realization that what I thought was a reputable company is not to be trusted.

title: Forced Upselling is not a good practice for Rentals Owners
content: I own 3 rentals and have used the Deluxe version for the past 5 years to enter the schedules for these rentals and didn't upgrade to the Premier version as all it offered was a Wizard to enter the data. This year they required me to purchase the Premier to even have manual access to the forms. Upselling me this for $30 is not a good practice. I'm looking into geting my money back after filing as they used to have a 100% satisfaction policy.

title: Only Reason to increase profits at customer expense.
content: I have been doing my own taxes since 1994 using Turbo Tax. Started after seeing that was what my Tax preparer used anyway. I have not bought it this year. Not mainly because of the missing forms , as I do not need them. BUT really in support of all those who do and now have to pay more. This is simply a method of making more money for Intuit. Nothing else. That is what I object to. So, after all those years, I have purchased H&R Blocks Deluxe version. I did not find it any harder to use. Shouldn't after doing my own Taxes for 20 years. As for the TurboTax program, it is probably the same as always. But if you remove something , it should be cheaper. It is not. Same price as ever before. So Why? Its smaller. Less .

title: I just wanted to add my two cents to the ...
content: I just wanted to add my two cents to the outrage. I bought the same deluxe I have bought for many years, and then discovered it does not include Schedule D. And it is very difficult to contact intuit in order to complain. So I am complaining here.

title: Your fired
content: InTuit, Your BS explanation of what and why you pulled functionality is just that, BS. I have been in IT for 25 years and would never spew the crap you did to any customer. Your fired. You lost another long term customer.

title: Greedy! Also, read wikipedia about this company, they actively lobby against consumers!
content: I've used TurboTax Deluxe for at least the last 10 years, this is my last! TTax has been getting worse and worse each year anyway, now they try to screw their customers with not allowing the investment income. Fine, I paid the $32.xx (with tax) to upgrade this year because you offered the $25 back... but that's only because I had started my return by the time I figured out you were pulling this crap. Next year I'll try H&R Block deluxe for the first time... it's cheaper, includes more, and doesn't try to pull this crap. Hope Intuit goes down in flames in this move, you've lost this long time customer for good... there won't be a 2nd chance no matter what you do in future years!

title: Intuit or Out-of it
content: Thanks for all the input about turbo tax. Loyal customer moving on. Good by Inuit, looks like you are Out-of-it......Something to mention, HR Block software can import tax info from turbo tax. That makes it easy.

title: Ripoff this year if you have investments. Prepare to be gouged.
content: When you go to enter investments, a screen prompts you to upgrade to Premier for $9.99. When you go to make the purchase the amount is $30. When I contacted Customer Support, they stated "we're sorry about that but there's nothing we can do. Would you like to upgrade now?" Time to move on to another product that doesn't gouge you for having investments, especially one that doesn't pull a bait and switch within the software. I have used TurboTax for years but won't stand for this level of gouging and bait and switch built into the product.

title: A Once Great Product Takes A BIG FALL......
content: Too many changes (features taken away) to TurboTax Deluxe this year motivated by too much corporate greed reflected in a huge price increase makes this once great product almost worthless! Time to give H&R Tax Software a try!

title: Higher price and patronizing customer service--bye bye TurboTax
content: "We understand change can be challenging, especially when it affects you directly."????? Sorry, that patronizing statement alone has convinced me that it's time to give up on TurboTax--after 15 years of using nothing else. For the record, while legitimate change can be challenging, what we have here is a company moving functionality from a lower priced product to a higher priced product. That's not change. The software works the same way it used to. You merelyhave to buy a higher priced version to get what you used to get in the Deluxe. That's just plain greed.

title: Intuit lost me as a customer for its personal tax return software, as well as its business software.
content: Goodbye, Turbotax. I came to download the 2014 Deluxe version, as I have used this software for nearly two decades. I read the reviews and decided it was time to switch, because I refuse to be manipulated like Intuit is trying to do. I tried H&R Block personal tax software this year. I am delighted with how easily it imported my data from last year's Turbotax files. I also have to file a number of 1065 returns for businesses and trusts. Out of caution, I bought Intuit for those again this year. I had more troubles with that program to do those returns than I had with H&R Block to do my personal returns. Next year I will also try H&R Block for the business returns.

title: Thanks for the warning...switching back toTax Cut
content: wow, thanks for the tips that they gutted the program this year. I had been using Tax Cut until I switched to turbo tax last year because Tax Cut didn't have the e form needed to claim an electric vehicle credit...guess I'll switch back to Tax Cut then...

title: Blindsided and Angered by Intuit's Decision to Yank Schedule D from this Version
content: I buy and sell a few non-tax-deferred stocks and mutual funds every year. After years of me being a loyal customer, Intuit decides that their Deluxe version of TurboTax that I buy annually will no longer handle Schedule D. Really??? But never fear, for a mere $30 upgrade, Intuit will provide me with a version that can handle Schedule D. Maybe I should have been paying closer attention, but I never dreamed that the "upgrades" Intuit was making this year would include this clever scheme to milk us all for another $30 a pop. What an insult to regular customers like myself, and a bone-headed business decision by Intuit. I'll take my business elsewhere next year. If you file a Schedule D, don't buy this version of this software. Word to the wise.

title: I would have missed the change Intuit made to their great Deluxe tax line
content: Thank you fellow commentors. I would have missed the change Intuit made to their great Deluxe tax line. Truly unfortunate decision on their part. Just checked H&R deluxe pricing($44.99-$10=$34.99) compared with what I would need for investments reporting with TurboTax, i.e. Premier ($89.99-$10=$79.99), Thus delta is $79.99-$34.99=$45. No brainer, making the switch! What is interesitng to me is when they(intuit) realize the consequence of this decision, they will have to discount significantly next year to pull back their old customers that switched to H&R Block this year. From what I heard from fellow commentors is both (H& R and TurboTax) products are nearly identical in operation and quality, so I don't expect many issues in making the switch.

title: i purchased the deluxe without knowing that it does not ...
content: i purchased the deluxe without knowing that it does not support schedule D any longer. Now I am stuck with paying 48 dollars for this one and need to purchase premier to do my taxes...... not good

title: Warning: Deliberately Crippled Software
content: Deliberately crippled! I've been using TurboTax for many years and, yes, I *do* require Schedules D and E. What was worst about their deliberate crippling of Deluxe was the run-around within the software when I answered that I do have rental property income. I tried forms mode, I tried interview mode, I found myself in a loop. Total frustration. I wasted way too much time trying to figure out why something that had worked for years didn't work this year. Sending this back and getting a refund = another waste of my time. I'd give 0 stars if it were possible.

title: Switching to H&R Block after 19 years with TurboTax
content: I love TurboTax and have been using it every year since 1994. This year would have been my 20th, but have switched to H&R block. With Turbo tax removing the schedule E and D from the Delux version has been the final straw. Premier is simply too expensive, when I can buy H&R Delux including these schedules for ~$32 here on Amazon. I know one can use the forms approach manually with TurboTax to work-around this change, but to me defeats the simplicity and guidance of the interview, which is why many buy tax software in the first place. I see many have the same issue and I also see similar comments on Costco.com. I suspect Intuit will lose a lot of loyal customers with this move. I wish Intuit well. Please don't mess with Quicken

title: Intuit does it again...fail.
content: I remember many years ago that Intuit put a restriction on the number of times you could install TurboTax and the backlash that had. The continuing backlash with Intuit putting out a brand new version of Quicken for Mac that had less functionality that the 2007 version of Quicken for Mac. If you remove functionality from the Deluxe version that has been in the Deluxe version for as long as I can remember, then rename the product from Deluxe to something else. Hello H&R Block Deluxe, glad to meet you. You have the functionality I need.

title: In the past I have recommended TurboTax for clients that do not need professional tax ...
content: As a retired Enrolled Agent I am appalled that the industry leader in tax preparation software would remove functionality while maintaining the price of the deluxe edition. No matter how you spin it Mr. Meighan, this is nothing more than a blatant attempt to extort more money from customers by forcing them to buy a more expensive product. You really expect to charge $30 more to efile a return with a single line entry on Schedule D? In the past I have recommended TurboTax for clients that do not need professional tax preparation. In good conscience I can no longer do that.

title: So long TurboTax
content: I have been using TurboTax for years and years, and this is the tipping point. I will give H&R block a try. I understand it can import from TurboTax. It's too bad, I really was comfortable using turbotax, but their decision and implementation of the changes really is an insult to consumers intelligence. We as consumers not only can provide feedback on products by rating them but, by our purchase decisions as well. Hopefully the person who had this bright idea will pay the price and next year, I might be back. But for now.. so long TurboTax

title: H&R block works great, and transfers 2013 returns with no problems
content: I just switched to H&R Block software for the first time because of what you are reading about Turbo Tax raising prices and deleting schedules. i have used turbo tax for 15 years, but not anymore. I want to say, H&R block works great, and transfers 2013 returns with no problems. I see turbo Tax got the point and are starting to refund money. Too late, I've already switched. Whoever at Intuit made the decision to try and swindle their long term customers should be fired.

title: Make it to the end only to be duped
content: I've used Turbo Tax software to do my taxes for a number of years now. My tax return is very simple, very cut and dry. Again, Turbo Tax made it very easy, but at the end I felt swindled. I paid the $50 for the software, only to find at the end, I could not e-file my state return without being asked for my credit card # again so they could charge me an additional $19.99. If I didn't want to use my credit card to pay this fee then there was the option to pay out of my refund, but that charge was $34.99. What a racket. Perhaps this little fee slipped my mind from previous years, but I certainly didn't save any money buying Turbo Tax here. I've seen the other reviews regarding other software that is much less expensive and just as simple. For 2015s taxes, I'm going with a different tax software.

title: Bye bye Turbotax, Switching to TaxAct
content: Goodbye Turbotax. I've used TT Deluxe for over 20 years but this forced upselling, added to the fact that Intuit has done nothing to improve functionality and price for its 1041 products (no import of investment income and still bundled with unneeded 1120, 1065 and other business products) has made me look elsewhere. After looking around at price and functionality, I've landed on TaxAct. The offer for a free move up to Premier still won't let me help prepare tax returns for a poor self-employed friend who earns less than $15k a year; heaven knows why Intuit thought it would be smart to force those who can least afford it to use their most expensive product or do their returns by hand if they don't want to overpay taxes As a 30+ year CPA, at least 4 other family members will no longer be paying Turbotax this year on my recommendation. In order to get the full functionality we need for all the the types of tax returns we need, TaxAct is the most effective cost option. I'm glad I walked past the year end display at Costco and decided to compare prices before buying Turbotax. Stumbling upon the very low ratings at Amazon was eye-opening. I have also alerted our HR department at the 50,000+ employee organization where I work about the now obvious errors in the e-mail they distributed at work with our employee discount, suggesting that, consistent with prior years, Turbotax Deluxe would be the most cost effective option for most partners and employees, many of whom have significant investment and K-1 income as well as multistate filing obligations. I suspect many of these people will also look elsewhere, if not this year, certainly next year, after they realize that Turbotax Deluxe no longer does anywhere near what it used to and that after inputting nearly all of their information, they will end up paying significantly more for the injury of having to file tax returns in the first place. Time to lobby Congress to let the IRS have its own e-filing program as other countries and many US states do.

title: Bad news for Deluxe users
content: Started buying this product long ago, back when it was MacInTax. The recent news disheartens me and I will be trying out a different product this year. Not happy at all with fewer features for the same price point.

title: Pathetic
content: I am VERY glad that I have read the reviews for this year's version before purchasing. I have been using TurboTax for at least 20 years now and must say that for the past 1-2 years that I have had to pay more than in years past. To hear that I will have to pay even more is absolutely ridiculous - especially as most of my income is W-2 save for $5,000 self employed...ie not even worth paying even more money for. I refuse to be nickle and dimed any longer and plan on moving over to H&R Block like many others. Good riddance TurboTax! You just got too greedy!

title: Turbox Tax 2014 A Disaster
content: I have used Turbo Tax for years and never had issues. This year it's a big mess. When I tried to use my credit card to pay for the state e-file, my Kaspersky blocked it as the SSL connection used by Turbox Tax was not safe. Tried to call TurboTax on Monday to resolve it and was put on hold for 2 hours and no on picked up. Called again on Tuesday and got a call back in one and a half hour. Paid the $19.99 using my credit card and was given a reference #. When I tried to use the #, Turbo Tax rejected it. Tried to call Turbo Tax again and the call was not returned. I will call again to get this sorted out. I will never use Turbo Tax again.

title: Furious at being gouged
content: I've been a loyal TurboTax for years. One of the benefits of using TurboTax, particularly TurboTax online, was that my past years' returns were always available through their website. This came in handy when I needed to look up my kids' SSN, for example. Or when I needed to review my previous year's return in order to identify my AGI so that I can get a e-filing PIN from the IRS. This year, however, all previous returns are locked unless I buy TT Deluxe. So... in order to E-file, I either need to get a copy of my return from the IRS (HA!), or buy TT Deluxe.

title: Goodbye TurboTax!
content: I have been using TurboTax many years now and WAS very happy with the product. Inuit is a shining example how the rich keep getting richer and the poor keep getting poorer. Thanks to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel and the Wall Street Journal for shedding light on Inuit's greed. Goodbye TT and hello to H&R. "Raising TurboTax Prices, Intuit Kicks a Hornetâs Nest Intuit, maker of the popular TurboTax tax-preparation softÂ­ware, has infuriated many longÂ­time users by requiring them to buy more-expensive software to complete their 2014 tax returns. Starting this year, people who prepare their taxes on a personal computer canât use TurboTax DeÂ­luxe if they want to electroniÂ­cally file common tax forms, inÂ­cluding Schedule C for a business, Schedule D for capital gains and losses or Schedule E for rental property. Instead, they must upgrade to the Premier or Home & Business versionsâ which cost up to $30 more than the $50 Deluxe version a s of Thursday. Customers with simpler reÂ­turns face a similar issue: They can no longer use TurboTax BaÂ­sic if they want to itemize deÂ­ductions (such as mortgage inÂ­terest or charitable donations) on Schedule A , instead of claimÂ­ing the standard deduction of $6,200 for a single filer or $12,400 for a married couple. Now, they will need to upgrade to TurboTax Deluxe, which costs up to $30 more than the $20 BaÂ­sic. People who use TurboTax to prepare their taxes online faced similar issues last year. As news of the change started to spread two weeks ago, longÂ­time users took their outrage to the Internet. On Amazon.com, reviewers posted more than 1,200 negative comments, comÂ­plaining of âbait-and-switchâ and âprice gouging.â (Journal readers sounded off in a b log post.) âThe company seems intent on fleecing t he customer by inÂ­creasing the price with no prodÂ­uct improvement,â says Don Rickelman, a retired entrepreÂ­neur in Naples, Fla. In the past, he says, he has used TurboTax Deluxe to report his investments, but now, like many other users, he is considering alternatives. TurboTax spokeswoman Julie Miller says customers surprised by the change can call the comÂ­pany at 800-445-1875 and âwe will work with them on a caseÂ­by- case basis.â Several who have called said they were given free downloads of TurboTax Premier. âLaura Saunders The Wall Street Journal "

title: The best example of how to alienate long-term customers that I ...
content: The best example of how to alienate long-term customers that I have ever seen. Silly me--after years of using TurboTax Deluxe I now find that it will no longer work for my needs (I didn't read the small print). The ploy is way more egregious than the typical consumer product downsizing scams. Shame on Intuit--this is the closest thing to fraud that they could legally perpetrate. (update:To clarify--nothing in my tax filing has changed for many years--I need Schedules D and E and sometimes C for minor income--but now Intuit in its cynical wisdom has apparently decided that I should pay an extra $30 in order to have those schedules in full digital glory. So they've basically almost doubled my cost so that I can continue to report less than 10% of my income). Their excuses make no sense whatsoever. This is my last ever purchase of their product.

title: TurboTax stores our SSN, Name & email in an online database - Hackers are delighted!
content: I've just read a story on USA Today http://americasmarkets.usatoday.com/2015/01/27/turbotaxs-database-knows-your-secrets/ that describes how TurboTax has a web site (search the site for "2014 $25 rebate") that requires your social security number. This means, that TurboTax has saved your personal financial information (e.g. SSN, Name, email, and more?) and it will be available to hackers online if the database is breached. In light of these security issues, this year I have decided reluctantly to skip TurboTax in favor of H&R Block, and will try TT again next year. I really hope that Intuit gets less greedy (e.g. 50% price hike for Deluxe, and less features across the board) and I hope Intuit becomes less complacent about my personal online security ... in the meantime H&R is ethical, honest, has much better prices and does not price gouge. Am I the only person that is disgusted that Inituit (turbotax) is storing my personal and financial information on its personal servers? In this time of huge Internet security breaches (Target, Sony, Citibank, etc.) I have little or no confidence in the capability of Intuit to maintain the privacy of my personal financial information - especially since it is compliant with low-grade IRS standards that leaves me scared - because, with all the budget cuts, IRS security standards are probably the bare-minimum standard, i.e. crap, right? ... !!! I appreciate that my tax filings must be stored, but I resent that my personal information is potentially compromised online. P.S. Intuit support has openly lied to me several times (10+) when I called to question them about maintaining the privacy of my personal information. They say that they do not store my SSN. They say that the SSN is just there for validation, but they do not store my SSN. This is totally false. If they validate the SSN I type in, then they MUST have it stored somewhere in order to validate against the email/name entered. When I asked how they validate the SSN without having it stored, they eventually caved in and said, yes they do store it - but it is in a secure database - I wonder how much they are lying about that too. Probably the flimsiest cheapest, easy-to-hack security available. Bear in mind that Intuit quickly rushed this rebate to market because of customer complaints (see USA Today story above). It looks like they just went for the laziest, cheap (crap) solution that was convenient for the company, despite compromises to customer security. They are not trustworthy in my opinion.

title: Intuit Ripoff Offer
content: What a ripoff!!! So Intuit is so kindly allowing me to get a $25 refund now that they made it so I have to upgrade to Home and Business for $90. That means I give them an additional $40 for their screwup. Sorry, Intuit, I know my math better than that! I've used TurboTax since the mid 1990s to do my taxes - this is the last year for that, in fact I'll most likely just eat my loss on this useless software and go to H&R Block. Since I have to give a star rating, I checked 1, but in reality I'd give them negative star for their arrogant attitude.

title: Shame Bottom line rules!
content: It is a shame that Intuit took the route of decimating their Deluxe product. I have used Turbo Tax Deluxe for the last 10 years and have been quite satisfied. Intuit, basic returns can be e-filed for free for your information. There are a number of providers who will do the 1040EZ and the 1040A for free. However, I am now considering alternative products. Unfortunately, Intuit seems to be doing this to all their products, including Quick Books, their so called upgrades every year do not amount to much, but the price goes up substantially. Very disappointing.

title: To: General Manager, Intuit Turbo Tax:
content: Like many of the responses, here on Amazon, I have chosen to purchase a perfect substitute software. Your response of, "We are giving $25 back if you purchased TurboTax Deluxe desktop software (CD or download) and filed your 2013 tax return and have to upgrade to TurboTax Premier or Home & Business to file your 2014 return." lacked the response that many of us are/were seeking. Not knowing your customers' needs is a huge problem for Intuit. Good luck with the mess you and upper management have created! Long time Customer, no more. Chuz

title: Bait and Switch
content: I did not buy TurboTax Deluxe from Amazon--I bought it from Sam's Club. I was working on my taxes today and got to where I needed to input data from sale of a second home (on 1099-S) only to find that I was forced to purchase a $30 upgrade in order to file my taxes. When I purchased the software, I read carefully the differences between the versions. There is nothing anywhere on the package that indicates that the Premiere version was required to file my taxes. I have used Deluxe for several years and have always been able to file Schedule C and report sale of second home. There is absolutely nothing on the package that informs the unknowing buyer about what version you need to purchase OR that you will have an in-app purchase. Classic Bait and Switch. Now TurboTax is "generously" offering a $25 rebate if 1) you used Deluxe last year, 2) have already filed your taxes and 3) used the CD or download version. But the upgrade is $30. I should not have to pay another penny given that there is nothing on the package to inform me that I should have purchased the premiere version to begin with. Shame on you TurboTax. I can tell you that TurboTax has lost a loyal customer. I have used TurboTax since it was first released. Nevermore. I will never purchase another Intuit product. In fact, I am going to get the free H&R Block Deluxe and try it out this year. Next year I will be using another tax product. I don't care if TurboTax decides to give their product free.

title: Goodbye Intuit. You made the decision easy.
content: This is customer disrespect beyond belief--with a huge dose of arrogance. No Schedule D in a "Deluxe" version? Are you kidding? But they didn't stop there--you can Go To Forms and SEE the Schedule D--but you can't fill it out manually. And if you want to go old school and fill out Schedule D in IRS-issued paper format and enter the result in TurboTax's 1040 form? Ha--they blocked that too, chump. But they'll gladly upgrade you to Premier for $30 more--all of which Intuit can keep for themselves and share nothing with a retailer. Let me mention that Costco is selling Premier for only $15 over the price of "Deluxe". With this as background, go read TurboTax's EULA--do you really want a company like this to have that kind of rights to the SSNs of you and your children plus a complete history of your finances? It's a waste of an Amazon star, but there's no lower rating. Update: It gets even better! Costco let me exchange Deluxe for Premier (again only $15 more compared to Intuit's in-software upgrade for $30.)---Kudos to Costco!. BUT, having started my return in Deluxe and installing Premier, the return only opens in Deluxe even after DELETING Deluxe from my Mac!! Is this a means to get chumps to pay $30 with every cent going to Intuit? Update 24-Feb-2015: Intuit: DON'T BE EVIL !!! After entering all my data offline (I don't like my tax files open while on-line), i discovered it's IMPOSSIBLE to print my tax returns unless I go on-line and use Intuit's "Secure Printing Service"!!! Guess what? I don't need their lousy, data-collecting secure service, I was going to print wired up to my own printer. How DARE Intuit force everybody to put everything through them....I guess it's off to the Post Office to get the IRS paper forms and transcribe all by Turbo Tax entries by hand. Thanks for nothing Intuit. Good riddance. (I don't believe ANY of those 5 star ratings are genuine...once Intuit started getting pummeled by negative reviews, they probably assigned some people to write positive reviews....Don't be fooled. Here's an answer I found on-line: HOW DOES ONE PRINT FROM THE CD VERSION WITHOUT GOING ONLINE. THE PROGRAM FORBIDS OFFLINE PRINTING. Starting this year, Turbotax CD/download versions will not permit people to print tax forms when offline. If you try to print while not connected to the Internet, you receive the warning "There was a problem connecting to Intuit's Secure Print Service. Please check your Internet connection or try again later." Even if you are not interested in connecting to Intuit's Secure Print Service, you cannot print or save to PDF without sharing your entire return first with Intuit. They prohibit you from only printing locally on home, cable-connected printers. The result of this is that people who tried to be safe by never going online with tax data, are this year being forced by Intuit software to expose all their sensitive tax information files to the Internet and Intuit print server, even though they do not wish to. I have spent four days trying to contact customer service without success. If a company really cares about you, they will at least provide a way to contact them.

title: Horrible price hike
content: Last year was my first year filing a US tax return and I was quite satisfied with TurboTax 2013 and was planning to buy TurboTax 2014. Luckily I read the reviews here and found out before buying that they are now forcing me into a pricier version, since I hold some stocks. It's a no brainer to use H&R Block Deluxe this year, which costs roughly half and provides the same easy guidance as well as imported my 2013 TurboTax return flawlessly.

title: If I leave this time, I'm not coming back.
content: I've been a TurboTax customer since approximately 1997, with the exception of the year TurboTax made its last stupid PR mistake - that of installing a DRM system that prevented me from re installing my software (which I do an average of every other year because of computer changes). I left TurboTax that year for a competitor. I returned the next year, when they retracted their decision and were sincere enough about it for me to trust them again. Now I am faced with a similar dilemma. I use Schedules C, D, and E. Schedule C is for a business that makes a piddling amount of money, but requires mileage deductions which are almost certainly not supported on the downgraded Deluxe version of Schedule C. I have investments that often require the use of Schedule D. I receive $500 in rental income annually (with no applicable deductions) which requires the use of Schedule E. That drives up my price 67% - not because my tax situation has changed over the past 2 decades, but because TurboTax has decided to downgrade the product I have bought for nearly 2 decades solely to extract more money from me. The explanations offered are insulting - that because TurboTax created confusion by offering online and mobile products by the same name that were less functional than its CD based products that its only option to gouge its customers who have been loyal for decades by making our products less functional as well. And - that their failing was that they were not clear about the change (not that they made it in the first place.) No. TurboTax had the option of conforming its online and mobile products to the functionality that has always been part of its flagship product line. That is the choice it should have made - not offering a one time $25 - less in a single year than the ongoing annual markup I will have to pay because they have downgraded the software I have always purchased. My decision on tax software this year is pending - but I'm pretty sure that if I leave via SwitchToBlock@hrblock.com, I will not return. I was impressed with the responsiveness to customer complaints about its last PR nightmare, but that response came after I had already left for the year. But you don't get to drive me away twice and have me come back a happy camper. If TurboTax drives me away this time, it will be permanent.

title: Good Bye Intuit - from a Long Time Customer
content: I have been a user of TurboTax for 10 years or so but I am switching this year. Not including the Schedules C and D in the Deluxe edition, as had been done in previous years, is irritating enough. But then forcing me to pay substantially more to accomplish the same thing Ive done in prior years, without communicating this, is slimy and unethical. And Intuit's VP attempted to justify this bait and switch with some phony explanation that insults my intelligence. I'm gone Intuit- going to purchase H&R Block's program this year.

title: Dumping Turbotax after 15 years!
content: Intuit deserves to go bankrupt as a result of this greedy marketing decision. Whoever came up with this little idea to eliminate forms from the Deluxe version needs to be fired!! I have used this product for about 15 years but am returning mine and have ordered the HR Block version. If I could find a program to replace Quicken I would do that too since they always make you upgrade every two years to keep their online access. Greedy #$%@$#%'s!!

title: ... Turbo Tax for 10 years and have been very happy..
content: I've used Turbo Tax for 10 years and have been very happy...until now. Requiring an upgrade to Premier, just to file a simple schedule D is ridiculous. I am going to forego the convenience of auto import of last years return data, and move to H&R Block. This is likely Turbo Tax's "Net Flix" moment, where they tried to increase revenue, but instead have outraged the majority of their customers, and will lose because of it. Very disappointing.

title: TurboTax has betrayed royal customers
content: As many others have already mentioned, Turbo Tax Deluxe no longer supports schedule D. If you have investment income, you need to buy Premier. I have been using Deluxe for many years and bought it again without any doubt. I should have read customer reviews before buying Deluxe. I will return it and switch to H&R BLOCK DELUXE which still supports investment income. We should send the strongest message to Intuit for their betrayal to the royal customers.

title: I've been using TurboTax for many years as a paying ...
content: I've been using TurboTax for many years as a paying customer. The version offered this year has serious errors in it. Some of my income is entered on the wrong line number in Form 1040 yet it shows as the correct income in the income entry form. I have tried many times to contact TurboTax about the problem but they fail to respond. I have been a professional computer person for over 40 years and still can not get TT to correctly characterize my income. I can not use TT to file my taxes this year and they will not help me.

title: Competing products offer a better value
content: I have used TurboTax for nearly two decades. It gets the job done, is reasonably easy to use and was competitively positioned until 4-5 years ago when the the price began to rise. At the time TurboxTax was more refined than competing products so I was happy to pay the uplift. Around the same time in-product advertising was introduced along with increasingly aggressive up sell pitches and higher fees for electronic filing (especially for state returns). I acclimated to the unwanted noise but the polish was starting to wear off. Then came mandatory Windows services, buggy software on initial release and other installation nuances that soiled the anual experience. Fast forward to this season with a further reduction of functionality (forms) and even higher price points. Ouch. A rare two star rating ("I don't like it") accurately reflects my feelings toward this product. It will do your taxes but there are far better values. Update: Like others I received Intuit's mea culpa mailings and offer for a free Premier upgrade. I find this less than sincere given Intuit's long history of hammering customers across their product line (I also use Quicken and Quickbooks). And next season I am again faced with purchasing Premier at full retail price. No thanks.

title: Trimmed features and trust
content: Intuit seems to misunderstand the reason for customers' anger. Long-standing users like myself think that the company has been dishonest. Because we trusted TurboTax and were satisfied with past performance, we subscribed to annual renewals without anticipating a need to read each year's offer with a magnifying glass. Intuit decided it could easily boost revenue by trimming features (similar to shrinking a pound of coffee to 13 ounces) so that users would need to buy more.

title: Changes to 2014 TT Deluxe serve as great motivation to find a substitute!
content: Thank-you Intuit! Thanks to your enlightened decision to Cripple TT 2014, we've finally found the motivation to break our 20-odd year addiction to the program - with an alternative that runs less then half the cost! Now if we can only find a substitute for Quicken, we can be rid of its insistence that 3 year old programs should no longer function...

title: Have used Turbo Tax Deluxe (TT) for over 10 years ...
content: Have used Turbo Tax Deluxe (TT) for over 10 years. Now I find that they have eliminate Schedules C, D, E, and F from the Deluxe edition. If I want these schedules, I have to purchase TT Premier, at over twice the cost. They are offering a $25 refund if I purchase and file TT Premier, but what about next year? Will I still have to pay the inflated TT Premier price? No thanks. I can find a cheaper software (H&R Block) that does the same thing as TT Premier. Sorry, TT.....you just lost a customer.

title: TurboTax the new Windows Vista/7?
content: I've used TurboTax for the past 6 years to file my taxes. It seems like every year I do my taxes I end up paying more money for the same software. This year I was very confused about the changes and vast options available. It seems like Intuit/TurboTax has gone the way of Windows Vista/7 with too many versions that just confuses consumers. Just ordered HR Block Deluxe for 22 bucks. Bye TurboTax!

title: Scheduel C D & E not supported by 2014 Deluxe version forcing consumers to buy the Premier version for more money
content: Very unhappy with the pricing game by Intuit/Turbo Tax for this year's tax softwar. The company has "dumbed-down" the Turbo Tax Deluxe version - this year it does not allow you to prepare Sched C D & E which were available in the Deluxe version in prior years. In prior years, Sched C D & E were fully supported by the Deluxe version. Now you are forced to purchase Premier for an additional $30 just to get Sched C D & E. I have simple return but it does required C D & E. The company is clearly doing this to generate revenues and this is not the first time Intuit has disabled functionality or "dumbed-down" its software to make consumers purchase software again or pay a higher price for an improved version. I have been a a Quicken and Turbo Tax user for many years - probably over 15 - and I'm now looking at other options. I think the H&R Block tax software is very good and much less expensive. The Sched C D & E are included in the lower priced HR Block software too. I'm now checking to see if my prior year's Turbo Tax files/forms will transfer easily to H&R Block software. If not, I will lose some continuity but so be it. This disabling/gouging strategy by Intuit is not the first time. I think it is insulting to all inteligent consumers to switch pricing in this way and for the most part it is disingenous. I expect the pricing strategy will backfire on them. I could easily afford the Premier version but there is nothing to stop the company from taking the same strategy next year. Maybe next year Intuit's / TurboTax's Deluxe version will only let you file an IRS 1040 EZ and consumers will need to buy a "super premier" version at a much higher price to even use the software to file a Sched A.

title: Not as "deluxe" as their 2013 version
content: Forbes has an article on their site with instructions on how to take advantage of an offer from H&R Block to get a free copy of Block's Deluxe+State version if you switch. http://www.forbes.com/sites/kellyphillipserb/2015/01/08/tax-software-wars-heat-up-as-turbotax-makes-a-change/

title: Tax Preparer says goodbye to TurboTax - unless a change in policy is Imminent.
content: Even though I have worked for a different tax preparation service, I used TurboTax for many years for my personal taxes because I preferred its layout and functionality. But let me be clear. If TurboTax does not reverse this policy of limiting the filing of forms - to force unnecessary upgrades - I will never use or have TurboTax on my computer again. H R Block programs will work very well going forward. I really hope a change in this policy is coming. Otherwise this tax preparer will be saying Goodbye to turbotax.

title: Disgraceful product crippling by Intuit!
content: Absolutely disgraceful of Intuit to pull this kind of trick. Then to apologize by saying "we didn't communicate...", my gosh, how insulting. The problem is you got greedy and tried to trick people via this money grab, not that you didn't communicate the trick and money grab well enough--It came through loud and clear! Please consider H&R Block's software folks--I did, it works just as well, and they're obviously a bit more respectful of our intelligence!

title: Good Bye TurboTax. I was there with you in the very beginning but now we must part ways.
content: I've been a turbotax user from the beginning, when it was somewhat frustrating and awkward, and experienced it steadily improving over time. It had just gotten to where I really liked it. But based on my review of the changes in functionality and excluded forms this year I will be changing to another software. Good By Turbo Tax. You made an amazing mistake if you think it is an improvement to degrade a product that has had such a long-term loyal following. If you wanted to have a smaller, lighter more cross-platform "consistent" version as you claim, you should have created another layer and given it a different name instead of crippling and dumbing down the specific product that was working so well for so many of us, so that we have to pay you triple what we used to for the same functions.. Your claims are not credible. Instead you appear both disingenuous and incompetent. And now with the reputation of Quicken diminishing every year, my upgrade due for that product will also be changing. farewell.....

title: Intuit, fire your marketing department
content: Saw that schedule d isn't in deluxe anymore. That I'd have to pay twice as much. Bought hr block instead. Half the price and gets just as good reviews for years now. You screwed yourself intuit. As long as I had no reason to leave you and try something else, I didnt. Now hr block has an opening and if they do an acceptable job, I'll never buy turbo tax again. Was this what your stellar marketing department planned? Fire them.

title: additional cost for state filing
content: This is so deceptive, its not even funny. now i get why so many people are switching from turbotax. Label big an bold federal and state. But i some remote hidden print... .... oh we will let you prepare and print the state, but if you want to efile 20 bucks please, want that taken out your refund instead of a credit card, that will be another 40 bucks!. If i could get my $ back i will so send this stupid software right back from where it came.

title: TT loses another loyal customer
content: I guess you can add one more to the list of loyal TT customers switching over to another package. I've been using TT for 17 years now, I like the product. What I don't like is a company trying to pull one over on loyal customers or trying to force me to switch to a higher priced "tier" product to get the same functionality I've had for years. No thanks, I've had enough of these shenanigans from TT, I'm switching to H&RB.

title: TurboTax GM Apologizes for Messing Up
content: In the past few days, USA Today, the Wall Street Journal, NBC and others have run stories about the apology from Sasan Goodarzi, GM of TurboTax, who sent an email to buyers of TT Deluxe that begins "We messed up", and offers a $25 refund to the victims of this fiasco. I could not find the text of the email on the TurboTax or Intuit websites (no surprise there) but found a link on the NBC website that takes you to that email: https://turbotax.intuit.com/modals/goodwill-letter/ Incredibly, the email makes it clear that TurboTax has NO INTENTION OF RESTORING THE FUNCTIONALTY OF TT DELUXE!!! Goodarzi's lame excuse is that "...we made the product experience consistent across all TurboTax offerings." in other words, "It was a good move for us, and if it happens to cost you more, well... that's good for us too!" I can't wait to see next year's financials, when we'll know the impact of millions of FORMER customers who won't be back (and if Goodarzi survives)!

title: I'm glad I read these reviews before buying
content: I'm glad I read these reviews before buying. I've been using Turbotax since about year 2000, but not any more. I was willing to pay a little extra for it since I was used to it but now it is time to move on. The castration of Turbotax Deluxe shows me that Intuit doesn't value their customers.

title: Very unhappy with the customer service reply to my phone ...
content: Very unhappy with the customer service reply to my phone call regarding the change in the program this year. I had already installed the program when I heard about the changes. I will not in future years use the turbo tax program. They have lost a customer of many years Recently Turbo Tax decided to do the FREE UPDATE to Turbo Tax to everyone that needed it. That was the right thing to do

title: Blatant Greed
content: WOW! Blatant greed. I have been a long time user and lover of Turbo Tax and this latest development is just disgusting. They chose dollar signs over their loyal customers. They are too blind to see that the mass exodus of their loyal customers will lead to a lot fewer dollar signs. It boggles the mind sometimes how stupid companies can be. The competitors must be licking their chops. EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTING. Good bye Turbo Tax.

title: Such A Disappointment
content: I had been using this particular software for at least 10 years and had been happy with it for the first 9. Last year, it would not allow me to efile our state and federal forms, no matter what I did. Being a procrastinator, I waited up until the last minute to complete our taxes and because of the efile failure had to go fight traffic to drop off our returns at the post office, which turned out to be the most unpleasant trip to mail something ever. The traffic was horrible, people were not following the basic traffic laws, and there were so many unhappy filers trying to do the same thing, they were literally jumping out of vehicles in the middle of traffic and running to drop their returns into the bins on the sidewalk = super dangerous! Was willing to overlook the problems from last year and buy this again, until I read the reviews and learned about the price increase and removal of items my family needs to file properly. Have switched to HR Block Deluxe after reading recommendations and the more reasonable price. Will review that one when taxes are done.

title: Complete Ripoff!!!!!!!! Switching to HR Block..
content: Intuit has now gone too far.. For years, I have put up with these forced upgrades that amount to extortion, or at the very least bait & switch tactics. Both Quicken, and Turbotax have used these tricks to force money out of their customers. I will now switch both products over to their competitors. I am sure that they will make the so-called "free" upgrade as difficult as possible so people will give up and pay the ransom.

title: Long Time Customer headed to H&R Block
content: Count me as another long time disgruntled TT customer. Like others have posted having to call and complain to a cs representative in the hopes of getting a free upgrade is outrageous. I'll be returning my software under the 60 day money-back guarantee and going with H&R Block, which for this year, at least, is free.

title: TERRIBLE PRODUCT
content: I have used this version for many years and was happy with it. Now that it no longer supports schedule C, D and E it is worthless. How can you call your product "deluxe" when it soesn't support basic IRS schedules? Don't want to but have no choice than to switch to H&R Block deluxe version. Hope Intuit realizes the loss of a customer that will never be back.

title: Time to break the TurboTax monopoly.
content: I've been a loyal TurboTax customer for many years, but it has long bothered me how Intuit keeps jacking their prices up until it's almost like you could have hired an accountant to do your taxes. It is easy to use software, but I'm going to try H&R Block for 2014. Intuit has taken their customers for granted a little too long. I'm also really disturbed that in spite of the fact that I selected the option to keep all my personal data on my PC that Intuit has stored my data, including my social security number and lots of details an identity thief would love to get their hands on, and Intuit keeps it in a data base. I never authorized them to do this. It turns out that since you "e-file" using their system, they have to keep a copy, but they should have disclosed this, and they should bend over backwards to assure customers that our data won't go the way of customer data at all the other big companies that have suffered data breaches in recent years.

title: I did not realize until after I had purchased the product that TurboTax had made such a bad choice on product design
content: I'm a long time TurboTax Deluxe user. I did not realize until after I had purchased the product that TurboTax had made such a bad choice on product design. I assume they thought users would upgrade to Premier to get basic Schedule C/D utility. I contacted the TurboTax Customer Service # provided by Bob Meghian to let them know of my dissatisfaction. After they confirmed that I was a long term user they gave me an upgrade code to take my installed Deluxe to Premier. They clearly told me that next year I would need to purchase Premier. So I'm happy that Turbotax made this right but it took 25 minutes of my time online to get this done. I sincerely hope that TurboTax product developers listen to the outcry of long time users and reconsider making this a permanent change going forward. If they do then there are many users that might try H&R block or other online options. The cardinal rule of brand loyalty is not to give your competitors a chance to get their customers to switch. Unless Intuit wakes up they could lose a huge part of their customer base. Schedule C/D is a very basic part of the tax code and to think you've got to go to the Premier level to get it is just ridiculous.

title: It's not personal, it's business--and that goes both ways
content: I've have no problem with a business charging more for its products than its competitors. I also have no problem jumping ship to that competitor. Like many others I've been using TurboTax for years, and like many others, I'll be switching to TaxCut this year. I think part of Intuit's miscalculation is that tax software purchases are a matter of habit. Even if the value proposition to the new price breakdown were justifiable, the mere fact that customers are forced to reexamine the product comparison charts means that a good chunk of them are also going to now take the time to a look at the feature comparison charts and reviews of competitor products when in years past they would have just bought what they were in the habit of always buying. So while I won't be jumping on the "Shame on you, Intuit" bandwagon, I will add my one Amazon star to the collective "Intuit Dope Slap".

title: Done purchasing Intuit products that they keep removing features from, so you can pay extra for them..
content: Anyone familiar with Intuit products knows that the company generally reduces included features within a product in favor of charging for them as add-ons, or paid bonus content. They have almost too many versions of quickbooks to count, and within each of those versions, there are sub-versions that you also need to purchase. I have used Turbotax for almost 10 years, and have been happy that the "remove then charge extra for" mentality of the features was left alone with this product - until this version. Intuit has removed more functionality in this release, and makes you purchase add-ons for another $40. I'm done with being nickel and dimed by Intuit. After purchasing this version and seeing this, I'm also done being an Intuit customer of their quicken for my home expenses, and quickbooks at my business. Good going Intuit - Hope it was worth losing another customer across multiple product lines.

title: you've saved me a total waste of 50 bucks
content: Very thankful for the warnings put out here and in the media, you've saved me a total waste of 50 bucks. I was a former H&R Block user, and I have ample reason to switch back now. This ticked me off as well: http://www.propublica.org/article/how-the-maker-of-turbotax-fought-free-simple-tax-filing

title: TT I don't like it when my wife yells at me..................
content: Every year my CPA wife asks if I have downloaded Turbo Tax for our preliminary and final state and local returns. We have kids in school and need to do early returns for some of the applications. Anyway it's one of the sure and easy tasks I can perform and get my brownie points for. This year that all changed when I got my "Where are all schedules I need ??? Did you download the wrong thing????" That sent a shiver up the old spine and I jumped to and started researching what changed in Deluxe. As you all know I'm out of luck unless I pay for an update or get some sort of divine grace for the TT folks. I"m in software and this isn't how you treat customers. TT has lost my trust. I probably will bite the bullet this year but then load my entire return and convert it to HR Block's software. That will give my wife time to get comfortable and put us in position to make an informed decision next year. Since my kids will have jobs soon (hopefully) TT just booted more than just us since my kids and family all rely on my wife's help. No big deal I guess just half a dozen customers for HR Block. Not the way, or the time, to surpirse long term customers. Really, Tax season????

title: Switch away from Turbo Tax
content: Wish I could rank it ZERO. A loyal customer ever since I switched from paper to a computer. Used Deluxe the entire time - probably over 20 years. Yes, I have schedule C and schedule E. A townhouse we own and rent out for the past 6 years. I do all the work on a spreadsheet before entering into Turbo. Bought Deluxe weeks ago thinking, all is OK, then tonight go to start the return. Upgrade -NO THANKS! Thought - they ALWAYS try to get me to do it every year - NO THANKS. Wait - FORCED TO UPGRADE - YES, FORCED!!!!!!!! Then to say - oh, thanks for using Deluxe last year- we will give you a $25 rebate?? Isn't there something about bait and switch? I like others will be checking out the free switch to HR Block that they are offering when you email them a paid receipt or software code if downloaded. Such a disappointment from Intuit & Turbo Tax, guess I shouldn't be surprised about the screw over the customer attitude. Look around at all the failing businesses lately, one right after another going out of business. It would be worth it to hit the HR Block in the malls.

title: Another Customer Leaving Because of Deluxe Function Removal
content: I've been a TurboTax Deluxe user for 15+ years, but not this year. Their decision to eliminate the ability to efile with a Schedule D makes the product useless for my family. I refuse to pay the additional cost of the Premier edition when other solutions are available at much lower cost. It's been fun Intuit, but so long!

title: I sounds like H and R Block has a very suitable replacement
content: Oh my goodness. I cannot believe that Turbo Tax Deluxe will not allow me to file a Sch D electronically. They are WAY misguided if they think only a minority of their users need this capability. And I think they are misguided if they think even their loyal customers don't object to a huge price hike, to buy a different product ("Premiere" ) to get the same functionality they had in years past with the "Deluxe". There is nothing Premiere about filing a Sch D. I started using Turbo Tax when it first came out on floppy discs, it was $5 I think, and I got Quicken free if bought together. Even faithful users will leave if provoked this badly. I sounds like H and R Block has a very suitable replacement. That was a really bad move on Intuit's part. What were they thinking?

title: Another unhappy (and soon to be former) Intuit customer
content: Do not buy TurboTax or any Intuit product. Intuit has scammed us and most likely will do it again. Count me as another lost customer. Since I am not rich I have used TurboTax Deluxe for years to file all my tax returns. This year I purchased TurboTax Deluxe, again, without reading the fine print (my mistake) regarding Schedule D. I soon discovered that I should have bought Premier but had already opened Deluxe and could not return it. Had to upgrade online to Premier which cost $30 for the upgrade. Yes Intuit has apologized and offered a $25 rebate--but the online upgrade cost $30. Read the terms and conditions of this offer. It is not a simple or easy procedure. No doubt that it was deliberately designed to discourage applications for rebate. Next year everyone should investigate the cost of hiring someone to complete your tax returns. Consider the time you will save by paying someone else to complete your tax returns vs the cost of TurboTax and the hours of time that you spend reading instructions and completing the forms. My guess is that those of us who have been using TurboTax have been working for less than minimum wage. If I do decide to complete my own tax returns next year I will using a competitor's product.

title: Intuit Lost a Longtime Customer Today
content: I was going to buy Turbotax deluxe today, but stopped when the list of functionality didn't look 'right' to me. I'm glad I did and read the reviews. This is a major price increase on Intuit's part. After 20 years using TurboTax (TurboTax 'multimedia' for tax year 1994 was in my old software box) I'm finally going to explore the alternatives

title: Like so many others here
content: Like so many others here, I am now a "former" TT Deluxe user after many years of using the product. I will be switching to HR Block or Tax ACT this year. Good luck Intuit with your very bad move, which can only be seen as corporate greed believing arrogantly that it can rest comfortably on the goodwill of its long term customers.

title: Time to try something different
content: I have used Turbo Tax since its very first DOS release. Have used the Deluxe version for years to handle basic investment and Schedule C small business. I am not willing to pay double what I have paid in the past and have no intention of reverting to paper form filing. I guess it is time to try something new.

title: Large price increase if you want same functionality it's had for years and years.
content: I'm in the same situation as others here. I have a very small amount of items that require me to use the missing forms. After years and years of using this software, they suddenly want double the amount of money for the same functionality they had before - not a small increase, a 100% increase.

title: Have 1099 forms or any Schedules? Gimme 99.99*
content: Just when you expect that you would get the same reliable product that would fulfill your yearly needs, Intuit decides to stagger it's features where each package charges you more for what was standard in years past. Deluxe is now Basic and Home and Business is now Premier/Deluxe in terms of fulfilling you tax requirements. Ultimately you might as well just go straight to to TurboTax Personal and Small Business/Home and Business for $99.99*! This is likely my last year buying TurboTax and I'll likely take my business elsewhere with regards other Intuit applications.

title: TurboTax is GREEDY!
content: I have been a TurboTax deluxe user for years and years but never again. Their greed at requiring users to pay almost $40 more in order to file Schedule C and E makes me furious. They offer a $25 rebate if I pay the extra $40. That is as laughable as their greed. TurboTax is a company that I hope bites the dust.

title: Greedy Money Grubbing Btards and Hamstrung TurboTax "Deluxe"
content: Intuit, you greedy b*stards! You've removed Schedule C from the Deluxe version. I've heard your pathetic!!!!!!!!! excuses as to why you did this, but really, it's just a matter of pure greed. I've used your software for more than 12 years in a row but I think it's time to look at the alternatives. I hear the H&R block software might be pretty good and they haven't hamstrung it like you did.

title: Well done Intuit!
content: ... You have lost yet another long-time (over 15 years) TurboTax customer. No more Schedule C or D in Deluxe means your loss is H&R Block's gain. MBA students in the future will no doubt be tasked to study this entire sad episode as an example of how NOT to treat customers.

title: Price Gouging Greedy Company Paying for Smith's Real Estate Investments in Detroit
content: I have been using Turbo Tax since its inception. With their current business strategy I say goodbye to them. Hello H&R Block! Intuit prove you are sincere and fire the executives who did this. Oh, love your security! All that money spent and you make the product worse.

title: Turbo Tax lobbies Congress against simple tax filing...
content: I've used this for years, but won't anymore. Aside from all the complaints here, potential customers should read about Inuit's (Turbo Tax's creator) lobbying of congress. One article reports that they spent around $11.5 million lobbying against simple, "return free filing," where the IRS would basically create your return for you. Of course, that would make Turbo Tax obsolete. In any case, this is certainly a company that does not deserve any consumer support, as they actively try to make their customers' lives more difficult than they need to be. Check out Liz Day's article, "How the Maker of Turbo Tax Fought Free, Simple Tax Filing." You won't want to support this company after you read this.

title: NO NOTICE PROVIDED
content: What I hate about Deluxe 2014 is that it no longer can handle investments that need Schedule D. All prior years of TurboTax Deluxe have been able to do Schedule D, but not 2014. There was no notice of this change to us TurboTax users that we'd have to buy the more expensive Premier version of the software to do Schedule D.

title: Not happy with TT changes.
content: I never considered that I might have go to another tax preparation software after using TT for so many years, but I will be moving on to another company for my income tax preparation needs. The H&R Block software is getting some pretty solid reviews.

title: Intuit is Losing Another Longtime Customer
content: I've been using TurboTax for around 20 years. I will no longer be using this product. I came to Amazon today to purchase the 2014 version so I can start working on my taxes. Good thing I read the reviews or I may not have known about the functionality change and subsequent price gouge. It's apparent from the reviews here and the reports from the mainstream press that Intuit's customers are not happy. So how does Intuit respond? They tell us we're just a small minority of their customers who apparently don't matter. An 800 number is provided so you can call and beg. Depending on your negotiating skills, you'll get anything from no help to a full free upgrade. Intuit's lack of customer service has cost them this customer. H&R Block is willing to do something Inuit will not, make things right with the customers. I will be taking advantage of the H&R Block offer and moving on.

title: Such a stupid stunt to not include Schedule D support in Deluxe
content: A long time Turbo Tax customer. No more. Such a stupid stunt to not include Schedule D support in Deluxe.

title: Don't let TurboTax extort you!
content: Just wanted to add my two cents on the controversy over TurboTax charging extra to do a return with investment income. Intuit has tried to extort money from me one too many times. They lost my business on Quicken and Quickbooks years ago. I should have seen it coming with TurboTax. I plan to try H&R Block.

title: Like others, a long time TurboTax user that recently ...
content: Like others, a long time TurboTax user that recently discovered the irritating product changes and the laughable Intuit rationale. Moving on to another solution.

title: Intuit Gives You Less for More Money
content: Less features for more money than previous years. Intuit continues to nickel and dime you at every corner to the point where its becoming cheaper to hire someone instead. I will not be buying another Intuit product ever again.

title: TurboTax Deluxe changes may prove costly to Intuit
content: If I could give this zero stars, I would. Turbo Tax Deluxe no longer supports schedules C, D and E. Having to purchase the upgrade to get these schedules basically doubles the price of this software. I've been a TurboTax customer for years and years, but not this year. I'll be using the other guy's tax software this year.

title: Abandoning TT after decades of use due to foolish corporate greed.
content: Now that they have downgraded the Deluxe version, why would anyone buy it? I have been a TT user for decades. Although I bought the TT premier version last weekend, I'm voting with my wallet and returning it since I haven't opened it. My taxes are fairly simple so I'll do it the old fashion way and it's free.

title: Shame on you Intuit- goodbye TurboTax!!
content: Count me among the many who are steamed about Intuit's bait and switch tactics. I have used deluxe for years to do my very simple schedule D and cannot see how removing features does anything other than force us to pay a higher price for something we are used to having. If they do not return it to Deluxe or take $30 off the price of premier next year (to match the price of what I am used to paying for the "old" deluxe), I will become a stalwart supporter of Block's software as the price is even less than what I am used to paying for Deluxe and does not preclude me from adding a simple schedule D. BTW, the $25 money back deal that was quickly rolled out does nothing for the future and seems like a half or quarter hearted attempt to give folks who are already hooked in this year and does nothing for the future. Shame on you Intuit!

title: Bad business practices
content: Looks like I won't be using TurboTax anymore.

title: I've always been curious how H&R Block's software compares so this looks like the ideal tax year to find out
content: I'm a schedule D user. I've always been curious how H&R Block's software compares so this looks like the ideal tax year to find out. Goodbye Turbo Tax.

title: Time to Evaluate and Make a Choice
content: Wish I could give lower than one, I was contemplating buying TT this year, but changed my mind, specially after reading defense and surprised pricing structure. While Intuit is entitled to make the changes to meet its fiduciary responsibility, of increasing shareholder value, I am entitled to mine - Save my Wallet

title: Turbo Tax fails to follow the tax law
content: Beware - Turbo Tax has revealed that they are using your social security number in their marketing attempt to recover from the disaster they created. To get a refund of $25(of the extra $35 or $40 you paid) you have to enter your social security number. so turbo Tax can compare it to a database of social security numbers they must be keeping of each customer. Thus, they are using their customers' social security numbers to give rebates in an attempt to recover from their flawed marketing strategy. That seems to me to be in direct violation of Internal Revenue Code 7216. using a social security number for "any purpose other than" preparing or filing the return is prohibited. Distributing rebates on its software product is not part of preparing or filing a tax return. From the IRS website: Internal Revenue Code Â§6713 imposes a civil penalty of $250 on any person who is engaged in the business of preparing, or providing services in connection with the preparation of returns of tax, or any person who for compensation prepares a return for another person, and who 1.Discloses any information furnished to him for, or in connection with, the preparation of any such return, or 2.Uses any such information for any purpose other than to prepare, or assist in preparing, any such return. Imposition of the penalty under Internal Revenue Code Â§6713 does not require that the disclosure be knowing or reckless as it does under Internal Revenue Code Â§7216

title: Goodbye TurboTax
content: I'm so glad I read these reviews. If I hadn't, I would have bought Turbo Tax Deluxe this year as I have done every year since 2000 just assuming it had Schedule D support. I'm not willing to pay $75 for Premier. I'll be trying out H&R Block.

title: Can't believe schedule D was dropped from this level TT!!
content: I can't believe TT dropped schedule D!...Dammm, I could go back to doing the yearly tax by pen and brain for what they have left from the old 'Deluxe'. I am now a FORMER TT user of many years!!! You killed it!

title: The bait-and-switch for the Deluxe version users (taking out a ...
content: The bait-and-switch for the Deluxe version users (taking out a whole raft of schedules, with no warning, and now demanding a charge to "upgrade") is outrageous. I've used Turbotax for years. But no more. They've gotten their last dollar from me. I wrote the above in January. Now it's late March. They did eventually provide the missing schedules without charge, but now the software does "helpful" things like (1) Opens information screens BEHIND the main screen. (It took me a while to find them at all!) (2) Asks if I want to install an update, but gives me no choice whether to or not. After I OK the install, the whole thing hangs and I can't get to my (previously almost completed) return. GRRRRRR. If I could give less than one star, I would.

title: I agree with other opinions here for one star. ...
content: I agree with other opinions here for one star. This is second time that I recalled TurboTax try to fleece the customers. Some years back when they quietly limit the electronic filing to single return instead of five. Because of resulting firestorm, they patch the product and allow 5 returns again. I don't know they can patch the product this time. I have to take a look at Tax cut.

title: No Schedule D
content: I have to agree, removing schedule D is nothing more than a way to force a portion of Intuit's customer base into a more expensive product. Their VP can make all the justification for this he wants, but there is no justification to remove this very commonly used schedule from a product that has had it as long as I have been using TurboTax and that goes back to the 1990's. Vote with your wallets and use another program.

title: Goodbye Intuit!
content: Adding my voice to the din. Goodbye Intuit - looking for my Quicken replacement and I'll be rid of you. Thank you for making my choice clear!

title: Turbo Tax to Loyal Customers - Drop Dead!
content: I have been a loyal TT customer for over 20 years and shocked again by their price gouging with this new bait and switch to Premier from either Basic or Deluxe Version in prior year. I think that Bob Meighan has lost his mind in thinking customers will blindly follow him off the cliff. This should be the beginning of the end for Turbo Tax products. I remember Bob from Price Waterhouse as a good guy and do not understand where he lost his way this year. I will not purchase Premier and hereby end my relationship with Turbo Tax & Intuit after an over 20 year customer relationship. Remember Palm Pilot and Blackberry? Turbo Tax will be next with this arrogant thinking that they have a monopoly in tax software and can do as they please.

title: Iâm glad I realized that Intuit changed their deluxe version to ...
content: Iâm glad I realized that Intuit changed their deluxe version to not include all the forms prior to making my purchase this year. Bad move on their part, looks like a lot of people are moving over to H&R Block this year because of Intuits switch and bait. I purchased H&R Blockâs tax preparation software which is cheaper than TurboTax and so far have found it to be a much better product. Wish I did this years ago. I contacted Intuit about their decision to make this switch and they gave am a bogus response that it was necessary in order to maintain their accuracy guarantee. This sounds like they have an inferior product and they donât know or want to fix it. Again, check out the H&R software and put Intuit in the trash.

title: I feel deceived and ripped off by this product. ...
content: I feel deceived and ripped off by this product. I have used Turbo Tax Deluxe for years to do my taxes. This year they change the program ELIMINATING the ability to input simple stock capital gain data without a costly upgrade to the next level program (Premier). The deception is that you don't realized the change until you are so committed that you have no choice but to buy the upgrade. On top of that, had I known I had to have "Premier" I would have bundled with "QUICKEN" and taken advantaged of their rebate offer. Other than this deceptive price increase, the program works well as usual.

title: I almost downloaded Deluxe, just out of habit. ...
content: I almost downloaded Deluxe, just out of habit. I wasn't even going to read the reviews because "I THOUGHT" I knew the product. What appeared to be very skewed numbers caught my eye and thankfully I took the time to find out why. I have never considered Schedule D anything more than a basic form I have used for years. Bye, Bye TurboTax. Your explanation for the changes blew up my BS meter.

title: Loyal customers are not valued!!
content: Been a loyal user of TurboTax Deluxe since 1998. Never thought Intuit will do an undeclared price increase of TurboTax Deluxe. Product comparison on back cover is confusing. Need to upgrade to premier or switch to other tax software to report capital gains from few stock sales.

title: I switched to TaxAct and it was very easy. Now I'll never buy TTax again
content: They disabled ordinary stuff in TurboTax for some reason. I switched to TaxAct and it was very easy. Now I'll never buy TTax again.

title: Back with TurboTax
