My one problem with Turbo Tax happened when I elected to file my state tax separately at a later date. It would start me with my federal taxes even though they had been e-filed. I would try to file my state tax but my federal tax would still come up first, Perhaps I didn't navigate properly, but it was most annoying. By accident, I hit upon the correct way to file the state tax. It should be easier to file taxes separately. Once federal is filed, it should go directly to the state.

title: biggest disappointment ever. This year they shot themselves in foot ...
content: biggest disappointment ever. This year they shot themselves in foot with every paragraph beginning with "there is an extra charge", H&R BOLCK next year for me.

title: TURBOTAX charges TWICE or NO SALE!
content: Tuirbotax Charges TWICE! The Picture below Shows what Turbo is asking me to do AFTER I AREADY paid for the CD! I Can NOT even fill out State Form without Paying AGAIN!

title: Works for the average filer, but now with fewer features.
content: It suits my needs, but I can understand others' complaints. Selling the same item as in 2013, but with fewer features at the same price is a poor choice on their part.

title: Works great, easy to use as always, and free upgrade to premium or home/business
content: This version will auto upgrade to premium or home and business if you need the features. After all the complaints from customers about missing forms, Intuit decided to basically upgrade everything for free. Works great and easy to use as always. I tried H&R Block software and it was pretty difficult to use, regret paying $30 for it. Hopefully Intuit will make things the way they used to be next year and avoid all the negative publicity.

title: It seems like TurboTax is constantly trying to get me to upgrade
content: It seems like TurboTax is constantly trying to get me to upgrade. I feel like I am getting ripped off. I have used TurboTax for years & seems they are getting worse.

title: No other software makes the forceful and coercive nature of ...
content: No other software makes the forceful and coercive nature of paying taxes more convenient and at a such a low cost. Thank you Intuit for providing a modicum of efficiency to the bloated regulatory mess that is the American tax code. Heroes! You could pay a CPA firm hundreds, maybe thousands, to do your taxes or you could click the Buy Now button and save yourself some money that you'll end up sending to Uncle Sam anyway!

title: One Star
content: Did not do what I needed.

title: One Star
content: better off to pay someone

title: Too little for too much
content: I won't b buying TT anymore. I have been getting it for at least 20 years and usually the higher software packages. This year, aside from the cost of just this software, I had to pay more than $30 to file my state and then there was another $30 or so to efile. This is a rip off. It ended up costing me close to $100 to file my 1040 EZ return. No more. They have gotten too expensive.

title: Failed to identify a very common deduction for previous year ...
content: Failed to identify a very common deduction for previous year state taxes paid. If I had not caught the omission myself, Turbo Tax would have cost me over $500.

title: Great support
content: I have used Turbo Tax for several years now and appreciate the simplicity and the low cost. This year I encountered a situation which I couldn't resolve on my own and called a Turbo Tax advisor. All my questions were answered with complete explanations by a personable gentleman. I could see this discussion costing me a hundred plus in a professional office. Thank you!

title: I am a 10+ user. I bought it at ...
content: I am a 10+ user. I bought it at Costco a week ago. Today I found it did not allow me to process my stock investment. Today I returned it to Costco immediately. Will find a replacement in a few weeks.

title: Questionable Pricing!
content: They underhandedly raised the prices on me half way through my return. I called and spent an hour on the phone with them and they were unhelpful. They also removed some features from the Deluxe software and are charging even more for the same thing I bought last year.Went to H&R Block software and it was more than half the price. I used to be a customer of Turbotax: NEVER AGAIN!

title: Works as it has in the past
content: I have been a TurboTax user since the DOS days of the late 80's and the latest TurboTax Deluxe edition download worked just like the previous versions - Very well. The process to file your federal and state taxes is very easy if you let the program step you through the various forms. The only concern I had this year related to the option to have all or part of your federal tax refund (if you are fortunate enough to get one) provided as a gift card. I was going to take advantage of that option until I dug into the terms. The third party bank that was handling the transaction would be able to market to me (I hate all the advertising being forced upon us these days) and would have more access to my information than I felt comfortable with (mainly an uneasy feeling regarding security of my data) so I canceled the gift card option. Other than that, TurboTax has fully met my expectations and unless Intuit does something foolish (like trying to get you to purchase a more expensive edition because they removed vital forms from a previous version) I will be returning again next year to do it again.

title: Don't buy this product
content: Easy to use but couldn't file state by e-file. Poor printing features. Have used for many years but this year's version is not up to par. Won't buy next year.

title: were caught off guard and caused unnecessary aggravation.

title: Intuit Finally Got It Right -- Sort Of
content: DESCRIPTION: After reading that TTax Deluxe had finally (and belatedly) restored its former functionality, I decided to give it a try. At first it seemed to be OK, even though one of our returns had a Schedule C (imported from last year's TTax Deluxe, which did everything we needed). This year's TTax Deluxe asked for the associated 1099-Misc (Schedule C) information, but, to my consternation, it never presented a menu for business deductions. So, not surprisingly, when I ran the Federal Review, the program discovered eleven errors, and when I asked TTax to correct them, it took me to various forms and asked for information to be entered there directly. No "step-by-step" was available at that point. Apparently the dumbed-down version was still operating. I then ran the Federal Review again, and the return passed the test. But when I went back to take a second look at the Schedule C information, TTax indicated that an upgrade to "Home and Business" was needed. I elected that option, and the upgrade was applied gratis. At that point, however, TTax indicated that many of previously-completed sections of the return needed to be reviewed. I went through all of those sections, and there was nothing wrong with any of them, so it's unclear to me why they needed to be reviewed. ANALYSIS: Once Intuit acknowledged that complaints about the dumbing down of TTax Deluxe were justified, the company should simply have restored the missing forms to the Deluxe version. Instead, they relied on user savvy to request the necessary upgrade, and the upgrade didn't apply seamlessly; instead, it introduced further complexities. I can well imagine that many people were flummoxed by Intuit's method of restoring previous functionality to TTax Deluxe. According to the Welcome screen, I'm now running TTax Home and Business, not Deluxe. BOTTOM LINE: So, I'm left with a couple of questions. (1) Will next year's TTax Deluxe include the forms that were eliminated this year? (2) If the answer to (1) is affirmative, will tax data from "higher" versions of TTax (Premier, Home and Business) import seamlessly into Deluxe next year, so I won't have to go through various user-initiated steps in order to get the Deluxe version to work without further hassles?

title: The software works, but Intuit created more trust issues this year
content: I've followed the thread started by M in SC for the past 4+ months. I've even posted a few comments. And now I just finished my own taxes. Tax year 2014 is finally closed. By now, the controversy about crippling Deluxe and the multiple bungled responses from Intuit have been discussed to death. I don't have anything to add that hasn't already been said in some of the thousands of comments. I hope Intuit fixes this for tax year 2015 and the lesson sticks for future years. This isn't the first time Intuit has tried to pull a fast one on customers and been caught. There was a TT controversy a few years ago about printing additional tax returns. And Quicken/Quickbooks - the file format changes with every new version, so once you upgrade you can't go back and you become a slave to whatever mandatory bundled services come with the new version. And every upgrade seems to have more required services bundled in. One good one - with Quickbooks, the Intuit self-service payroll service is only good for three years. If you're a Quickbooks customer and you use Quickbooks for payroll, even self-serve payroll - you must upgrade to the new version every 3 years to keep getting payroll updates. But this review is for Turbotax Deluxe, not all the other Intuit products. And for me, overall, it worked. I called the toll free number early and Intuit gave me a free upgrade to Premier, so I was able to deal with my Schedule E and Schedule K1. That worked. The installation went smoothly, the interviews asked all the right questions and, near as I can tell, all the forms looked good. I e-filed my federal taxes and US Mailed my state taxes. A text message came to my cell phone a few hours after e-filing that it was received, so the process was smooth. If I have to install TT on some other computer in the future and do something with my 2014 taxes, that will be a problem - but it's unlikely. And I have PDFs of all the forms. Finally, there's Turbotax VP Bob Meighan. Bob has been the public point man through all this and he's taken a great deal of abuse. Kudos to Bob for staying engaged and mixing it up, even in hostile territory. So overall - the software did its job and was easy to install and use. Bob Meighan is a visible spokesperson and he gives the best answers he can give, at least with product functionality related issues. That's worth five stars. But Intuit created a trust issue and I don't like looking over my shoulder for hidden gotchas. How am I supposed to trust software from a company I'm worried is trying to screw me? Even if not, I still find myself not trusting what Intuit says and always looking for a gotcha or some hidden meaning. That's one star territory. So we'll settle in the middle with three stars.

title: TurboTax works better - in spite of this year's hot mess.
content: Everyone now knows of the hot mess Intuit created when they crippled the Deluxe version's handling of Schedules C and D. And due to the strong backlash they got from the customer base they pivoted and made it right again by upgrading Deluxe to whatever higher version you need for no charge, plus promising to revert back to the old Deluxe functionality. Now that the dust has settled I hope whatever team that recommended the altered version of Deluxe were shown the door. I've been a loyal TT customer for 10+ years like many of you. And, duly insulted by Intuit's money grab, I decided to go with H&R Block. So if you were wondering which worked best...read on. In a nutshell I got a $600 higher Federal refund and a state tax penalty that was $155 less by using TurboTax. There are several reasons why. TurboTax does a more thorough job importing prior year's data and matching it side-by-side, making it much easier to note changes. H&R only imported my demographics. The interview process is more polished in TT, and thoroughly fleshed out my tax situation, which made it more straightforward to discover valid deductions. Here's two important examples where H&R faltered: I have an adult child who I can claim as a qualified relative, but the interview process totally dropped the ball. I had to drill into the forms to manually capture them as a dependent, an important deduction. Later I entered student loan interest from two lenders, but when I reviewed the final return only one of them had an entry. I again drilled down into the forms to find that a check box had been omitted on a lender, leading H&R to believe the interest wasn't tax deductible. A potential $2000 difference. And there was nothing in the interview process to have led me to make that choice in error. So even after correcting the flaws and running both programs all the way though, TurboTax still managed a more favorable result. H&R Block is cheaper - no two ways about it. And it works quite well. But I believe you have to be more astute to avoid unexpected results. And for those who are truly paranoid about an audit here is the difference between the programs. H&R will provide someone to attend an audit with you for free. TurboTax has a $60 fee, but the (optional) service from TaxAudit means they will fully review your return and do battle before the IRS. You have no involvement. Pick your poison. So there's my experience. What I got back by using TurboTax more than made up for the higher expense (and this year's profound aggravation).
